name: Petri
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

Multiply and spread in this strategic territory-claiming, piece-elimination game with a strong dose of chance for two to six organisms.

You Need

* A Chinese checkers set.
* Two 6-sided dice.
* A capture cup for each player.

On your turn, roll the dice, transform your pieces (either add or remove pieces on the board), then check for captures (based on the number of adjacent friendly and opposing pieces -- captured pieces, whether friendly or not, go to your capture cup).

The game ends when one player has no pieces left in play or in hand, or if there are no pieces on the board and all players have taken a turn.

If you have the most pieces in your capture cup at the end of the game, you win.

name: Wightopoly
description:
WIGHTOPOLY is concerned with business trade in the Isle of Wight (UK). The object of the game is to accumulate as much wealth as possible through the purchase, trade and development of businesses - the businesses themselves representing actual firms on the Island.

It has the following features:

- Businesses to buy, trade and sell.
- The ability (once you own all the key businesses in a colour group) to expand by building shops and superstores.
- Carisbrooke Castle - a place where you get sent when you have failed to pay your bills - though you are able to visit if you happen to pass by.
- The Learn 2 Drive Centre where you gain £200 by passing through.
- "Pay & Take" and "Good News - Bad News" cards.
- Mortgages
- Loans from "Rosie Jo".
etc...

Sound familiar to anyone?
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Billy Hamilton's Football Academy
description:
FOOTBALL ACADEMY is designed as a journey through the life of a professional footballer (soccer player). The game is designed by a former professional player - Billy Hamilton.

The game is conducted in three phases:

The Apprenticeship - three (game) years of learning the skills and demands of being a footballer, as well as performing the thankless, but necessary, tasks essential to the everyday running of a football club. This apprenticeship is the foundation upon which the professional career is built.

Professional Footballer - As a professional, the player strives to maintain a high standard, on and off the pitch. He becomes more involved in duties outside the game and must lend himself to charitable and promotional work. His good performances on the pitch may lead to international recognition.

Gain International Caps - It is the dream of every player to play for his country and win the World Cup.

The Apprenticeship stage is conducted by undertaking three circuits of the outer board based on a roll and move mechanism. Activities are driven by the actions required of the squares on which the playing piece lands. After completing three circuits any Skill and Effort tokens earned are traded in for a potential rating which determines which of four paths that player follows through the Professional Stage.

Progress through the Professional Stage is, once again, dependent on the roll of the dice with the effects of the square being detailed in look-up tables contained in the rule book. The idea is to proceed to the International Stage as quickly as possible, collecting goal tokens on the way.

During the International Stage players roll two dice (one advantage, one penalty) to progress. Dice rolls can be modified by the trading in of goals gained during the professional phase.

The winner of the game is the first player to enter the World Cup Winner zone at the center of the board.

name: Phoenix in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Phoenix, Arizona. It has spaces such as Camelback Mountain, Sun Devil Stadium, Scottsdale, Tempe, and Salt River. The tokens include a Coyote, Scorpion, Cactus, Sunglasses, Heart, and a Football. Cards include local events and staples of life in Phoenix.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Star Trek: The Next Generation
description:
STAR TREK: THE NEXT GENERATION is an abstract game themed to the popular TV/Movie Series.

The aim of the game is to explore the board, starting at the Launch Pad, in order to reach the Docking Ports of five of your colleagues. Movement is determined by the roll of a D6.

When you arrive at a Docking Port, using an exact roll of the dice, you collect a character (Captain Jean-Luc Picard, Commander William Riker, Lieutenant Geordi La Forge, Lieutenant Tasha Yar, Lieutenant Worf) which, if you do not already have it, is placed face up next to you.

Characters may also be "stolen" from other players by landing on the space on which their playing piece is situated.

The winner of the game is the player that is the first to collect his five colleagues and return with them to the Launch Pad.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Space Exploration

name: City Visions
description:
City Visions is a unique and exciting way to discover the city. It is a guide AND a clever game!

Tucked into a neat travel deck are 80 oversized photographic playing cards. The cards feature places throughout the city, including restaurants, museums, performing arts, landmarks and sporting arenas.

Each card is filled with a beautiful photograph and backed by three questions about the featured place; background information and a locater to help you get there. The game involves risk, strategy, knowledge and a little bit of luck.

If you guess all three answers you collect a card. The goal is to collect ten cards. Keep guessing until you miss or pass; you get up to three cards per turn.

Whether you're an avid traveler; a proud native or simply curious and eager to explore; City Visions is for you.

City Visions is now available in five cities: New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago (with 60 cards) and Washington, D.C.

name: Super Jock Baseball
description:
This is in the Super Jock series of sports games. You hit Super Jock on the head to make it do its action.

In Super Jock Baseball, one player has a spring loaded pitcher (Unfortunately, not activated by slamming its head!) who delivers to a Super Jock batter.

This is by far the hardest of the Super Jock games. Most often the batter strikes out ;)

name: Executive Venture
description: From the box cover "a humorous game of executive prowess"

name: Syracuse in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Syracuse, New York. It has spaces such as Erie Canal, University District, Armory Square, Marble Farms and Ice Cream. The tokens include a Salt Shaker, Snowman, Ski, Sailboat, Heart, and a Pretzel. Cards include local events and staples of life in Syracuse.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: BMX Challenge
description:
This is a really simple roll and move game.

Each player is riding a BMX bike across a track. The roll of a die determines the number of space you move. You get a second roll if you land on a space with your color. There are also some spaces where you draw cards,either with positive effects (yellow cards) or negative effects (red cards).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Daring Dice
description: Players bet against the luck of their opponents, daring them to beat the odds. The object of the game is to roll six of each kind and close out the categories on the daring dice. The first player to "bottle up" each category and score the most points, wins.

name: Wheeler Dealer
description:
Contents of the Game:

1 playing board, 3 dice, 3 packs of ‘Commodity’ cards (coloured red green and yellow) 1 pack of ‘Command’ cards (coloured blue) various denominations of ‘Credit’ notes, 6 playing pieces, 6 ‘At Risk Zone Cards’, 1 set of Rules.

Cards: There are 4 packs of cards which are placed on the playing board, as indicated by the 4 colour coded cards situated between the ‘inner’ and ‘outer’ circles. The 4 packs of cards are made up as follows:-

Red Commodity Cards – cheapest range from 500 to 1,000 ‘Credits’.

Green Commodity Cards – middle range from 2,000 to 10,000 ‘Credits’.

Yellow Commodity Cards – dearest range from 10,000 to 100,000 ‘Credits’.

Blue Cards – ‘Command’ cards – instructions must be followed.

This game can be played by 2 to 6 players aged 8 and over. There are 3 different levels of the game, each being a little more complex than the last. The first level enables you to get used to the basic idea. The second level introduces more advanced rules and techniques. The third level encourages you to play the game in its purest form, pitting your wits against the other players until a final winner emerges. (You will find a ‘Quick Start Guide’ on the back of the ‘At Risk Zone Card’.)

The idea of the game is to be the most successful Wheeler Dealer™ and depending on which level is played, be the first to have a total wealth of up to 3,000,000 ‘credits’. Players start with 8,250 ‘credits’ and a random hand of 4 red and 4 green ‘Commodity’ cards on level 1. Players accumulate wealth by selectively buying and selling ‘Commodity’ cards one at a time, until a ‘set’ of 3 or more identical cards has been built. Once a ‘set’ has been built it may be sold to the ‘bank’ for 2, 3 or 4 (sometimes more) times the ‘face value’. It is good practice to place the ‘set’ to be sold to the ‘bank’ in the middle of the playing board. ‘Commodity’ cards sold to the ‘bank’ are placed at the bottom of the coloured coded deck.

Players must start on the ‘outer circle’, from any of the blue spaces, in a clockwise direction. Players may only progress to the ‘inner circle’ when they have sufficient total wealth (150,000 ‘Credits’ level 1). As soon as one player reaches the ‘inner circle’ all other players are permitted to enter also, even if they do not have sufficient wealth. Wealth is accumulated faster on the ‘inner circle’, however, there are greater risks. All players must announce that they are going to enter the ‘inner circle’ before the dice are thrown. Before throwing the dice to move around either ‘circle’, players may buy one ‘Commodity’ card from any other player for 3 times the ‘face value’. Other players do not have to sell and only one card may be bought at a time. If buying a card makes a ‘set’ of 3 or more the player may also sell the ‘set’ to the ‘bank’ before throwing the dice to move around the ‘circle’.

Players may at any time during their turn secure loans on other ‘Commodity’ cards in their possession at ½ ‘face value’ which is known as the ‘At Risk Value’. Such cards must be placed on the ‘At Risk Zone Card’, unless they form part of the ‘set’ to be sold immediately to the ‘bank’. ‘At Risk’ cards may be bought by other players, when it is their turn, at 2 times ‘face value’. If asked, the owner of an ‘At Risk’ card must sell it to the other player, repay the bank the ‘At Risk Value’, plus 10% interest. It is good practice to place the ‘At Risk Zone Card’ to your left, thereby keeping your cards and money away from the other players.

Once the above options have been exhausted, the player then rolls the dice (2 ‘outer circle’ 1 ‘inner circle’) and moves his playing piece the number of spaces rolled in a clockwise direction. The player turns over the top card of the colour landed on and may buy the ‘Commodity’ card at ‘face value’. If buying this card makes a ‘set’, you must wait until your next turn before selling the ‘set’ to the ‘bank’. If a player does not have or cannot raise enough money to buy the ‘Commodity’ card or does not want it, the player must pay the ‘bank’ 10% of the ‘face value’ to cover the ‘Handlers Charge’ and the ‘Commodity’ card is placed to the bottom of the colour coded deck. If the player cannot raise enough money to pay the ‘Handlers Charge’ bankruptcy must be declared. When landing on a yellow space (outer circle), players have the option of turning over a yellow ‘Commodity’ card buying it or paying the ‘Handlers Charge’, or turning over a blue ‘Command’ card and following the ‘Commands’.

If a player lands on a blue space ‘outer circle’ a 5,000 ‘Credit’ bonus is paid to the player from the ‘bank’. The player also takes a blue card (‘Command’ card) from the top of the deck and follows the ‘Commands’ exactly. If a player lands on a blue space on the ‘inner circle’ no bonus is paid but a ‘Command’ card must be taken from the top of the blue deck and ‘Commands’ followed exactly.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Trading

name: Game of the 5 Fields
description:
From the designer's website:

"The Game of the 5 Fields could be considered a version of Chess at a strategic scale. It's an abstract version of the expansion of the civilizations during antiquity.

"You will be leading your people, represented by a Queen and her Princes, and you'll try to be the first one to build a City and 5 Fields to supply food."

From the rules:

"Players must make good use of the layout of the land to be the first one to reach the final goal: build a City adjacent to a chain of 5 Fields. In an advanced version of the game, players progressively discover the board which is blank at the beginning of the game."

name: Mil Mascaras Pro Wrestling Game
description: A game published and designed by one of early pro wrestling's most dynamic characters. In Mil's pro wrestling its all about the luck of the dice being substituted for the rehearsed high flying action of the ring. the game presents an almost interesting mechanic of designing moves, by joining coordinates, but who wants their camel clutch to be controlled by fate, rather than athletic prowess.
publishers: Bernie Lopez Enterprises, Mil Mascaras Corporation

name: Marble Quest
description:
Description
It’s a trivia game. It’s a strategy game. It’s Marble Quest! Test your knowledge and your skills in this unique game that combines 3 dimensional Tic-Tac-Toe with multiple-choice trivia questions in four categories; social studies, the human body, earth science, and pop culture. Three levels of game play mean the whole family can get involved. Play only with the rotating, 3-tiered Tic-Tac-Toe tower for an unusual twist on an old favorite or add in the trivia cards and the board game for an added challenge where players earn marbles to play on the 3-D tower by answering trivia questions. Game comes with game board, 200 trivia questions, 32 glass marbles, plastic game tower, dice, and instructions. For 2 – 4 players or teams.

Winner Top Toy of the Year Award 2004, Creative Child Magazine.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Educational, Trivia

name: Dugi
description:
AIM: Capture your opponent’s pieces by surrounding it on opposing sides. When your opponent has only two pieces left, or cannot move on his/her turn, then you have won the game.

SETUP: The board is a circle consisting of 7 rings, divided into 24 segments. There is a circle in the center called the ‘dead zone’. There are 12 black counters and 12 white counters. Arrange these on the board on the outer spaces (one per space on the outer ring of the board), with the black pieces closest to the black player, and the white pieces closest to the white player.

PLAY: Players take turns moving one piece per turn. The pieces may be moved ‘forward’ (toward or away from the center of the board) or ‘sideways’ (left or right around the ring). The pieces may be moved as far as the player wishes, but must not leave the board on the outside, enter the dead zone, move diagonally or ‘jump’ a piece in its way.

To capture a piece, you must move your piece so that it completes a ‘surround’, then remove the captured piece from the board.

Online Play


Super Duper Games


Released under Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial licence. Hosted here: http://superdupergames.org/rules/dugi.pdf

name: Bogyman
description:
From the instruction sheet:

"BOGYMAN"

"A spine tingling board game of strategy and risk for 2-5 players"

"About the Game - The Bogy man has risen from the grave, stalking the town of Homewood by night, and hiding in the shadows of the old abandoned mansion by day. The only way to send the Bogyman back to the grave is to enter the old mansion, find the nine missing pieces to the magic medallion, and assemble it. Four brave town's people have accepted the challenge even though others before them have tried and never returned. Their chances for survival are very small, but that's their problem."

Contents include:
Instruction sheet
Game board
28 cards
Five standard pawns
One six-sided die
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Olivia Coming Through! Game
description:
From the publisher:

So much to do and so little time! Olivia hops onto her scooter and races to be first to jump up and down on her bed. A “pedal to the metal” game, with many unexpected twists and turns.

name: Coronation Street
description:
A trivia board game based on the popular UK ITV Soap "Coronation Street."

Features a board that looks like the famous street and includes a "who's who" booklet.

name: Texas Politicos
description:
"A game of MONEY, POWER, and FUN For the OFFICALs and UNOFFICALS in and out fo the great state off TEXAS!

Dedicated to the FIGHTIN' and FUN LOVIN' members fo the TEXAS LEGISLATURE" (direct quote from box cover)

A satirical game about collecting enough votes and cash to achieve office in Texas. The bank in Sharpstown plays banker "under the table and from a brown bag," while another player (the election judge from Duvall County) tracks the winning conditions. The rule sheet is half a page long, and does not include any instructions other than setting up and winning the game. However, it appears to be a simple "roll the dice, react to square landed on" game while the players tour a linear board (the only path is to follow the outline of the state) until they can get enough votes and cash to reach the middle.

name: Bermude
description:
On a "living" board, the players must place all their marbles in a chain to win. A marble can move by jumping over another marble or a chain. Furthermore, if a move causes a triangle to be empty, the player can reposition it anywhere he wants, as long as it touches the board.
The ever-changing board and the player interactivity (every problem is solved by voting) make Bermude an original family game; but it is not as easy as it seems.

name: Shuttle Command
description: Answer space history questions to achieve your shuttle mission.

name: Bridge for Juniors
description: A simplified version of the card game, Bridge, with child-friendly card art.

name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
description:
Be the first player to collect five Golden Tickets and take the Glass Elevator “Up and Out” of the factory. (i.e. roll and move, ask riddles, pick cards and do what the card says).

Game promotes reading, making choices and counting, however reading is not necessary to play, so younger children can enjoy the game.

This game is being launched with the movie in summer 2005, and appears to be unrelated to the German game with the same name from 2003.
categories: Children's Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: On d√©coupe le monde en tranches
description:
At the beginning there is enough space. Everybody can build his own houses on his preferred continent. And then, everything becomes more complicated as places begin to disappear. Fires, alliances, treason... who will be the first to control 2 continents?

A visual game, mixing tactics and bluff... and where your allies of the moment can quickly become your enemies!

name: Monopoly: Napa Valley
description: Yet another version of Monopoly. Based on the more famous wineries of the Napa valley. Fancy tokens in the shape of wine related things.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Millennium Vacation
description:
The millennium is upon us and everything has gone haywire.

Power shortages cause the airports, gas stations, banks and others to be out of service.

Can you get to grandma and grandpa's house for their 50th anniversary, and then back home?

Play Millennium Vacation and find out!

Glow-In-The-Dark Millennium Vacation Family Board Game For 2-8 Players Ages 10 and up.

name: Bible Baffle
description: This game brings to life all of the history, wisdom and events of the Bible, as players recall facts from passages found throughout the Word. Questions are scripturally sound and drawn from the Old and New Testaments of the King James Version of the Bible. Biblical categories include: Old Testament, History and Geography, Prophets and Prophecy, Names, Wisdom, Letters, Numbers and Sequence, and the New Testament. Players try to move through the sequence of categories by successfully answering questions. Recommended for Ages 13 and up.

name: ASLingo
description:
The philosophy behind ASLingo is for school-age children and students of ASL, hearing or deaf, with proper guidance from experienced ASL users, to utilize their cognitive and perceptive skills with their knowledge of ASL in an expressive and receptive manner. Instead of being too linguistic or didactic about teaching ASL in a structured environment, the children and adults can have fun together while learning pragmatically.

Most of all, the players are engaged and delightfully attending to a bilingual game of bingo without stress. How many of us have learned basic economics, vocabulary and concepts through famous board games while cherishing the fond memories of playing with family and friends?

name: 'Dillos in Austin
description:
‘Dillos in Austin: A simulation for 2 to 4 ground-dwelling armored dasypods.

You think road construction is bad in your town? You should try living in Austin. Even without road construction, the signage is confusing and the drivers are absolutely nuts. The only thing that could make navigating the city more challenging is if the roads actually shifted and changed while you’re driving.

Object: Get from your home to the capitol building in the middle of town without getting captured by the ‘dillo hunter.

You Need:


Two 6-sided dice.
A city map. (provided on the website)
Road pieces. (provided on the website)
An opaque bag or other container.
five pawns of different shapes or colors – one for each ‘dillo and one for the ‘Dillo Hunter.


On your turn, roll two dice. If you roll doubles, the player to your left moves the ‘Dillo Hunter the amount shown on one die. If a pawn enters a space occupied by a stop sign, it must stop moving. After the ‘Dillo Hunter moves (if it moves), choose one of the dice you rolled. Look up that number on the Action Chart (Twist, Swap, Push, or a combination of these) and take the action indicated by your chosen roll.

If you land on the capitol in the center of the board, you win the game.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Switch & Tip
description:
From the designer:

This is not a game, I just feel terrible every time I get an e-mail telling me someone has bought it, I'm taking it off the net, those of you who have it have a really rare and useless PDF.

the following is ALL LIES!

Played on a 3x3 board with two pieces for each player, Switch and Tip is surprisingly small abstract board game. The two pieces act differently, one moves around the board and the other moves by changing places with other pieces. With two different ways to win there is a surprisingly large amount of depth to such a small game.

name: Let's Play Golf
description:
Let's Play Golf was originated to give both the golfer and non-golfer some of the thrills of golf right in the home, car, plane, or anywhere.

Players draw from different stacks depending how far from the hole they are. Each card tells you how you did and which stack to draw from next or how many putts it took to get the ball in the hole. The winner is who has the least strokes for 18 holes.

Includes 108 plastic-coated cards, score pad, pencil, and instructions.

name: Vinesque
description:
From the rules:

The play consists of collecting numbered Wine District Cards on the Vinesque playing board within the Yellow and Blue Zones. The Cellarer squares (Yellow Zone) and the Disaster Bin and Europa squares (Blue Zone) determine the players' fortunes as the game progresses.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: LETTERIP
description:
From the instructions:

Use the exciting combination of scrambled letters, fast clues and definitions to find the original word.

Step 1. Mix the cards up in each separate group

Step 2. each players draws a card from the 4 letter word category

Step 3. every player makes up a new work from the word they’ve picked

Step 4. First player begins by telling everyone their newly created work

Step 5. All other players must guess in 90 seconds what word first player originally picked

Step 6. A clue will be given every 30 seconds

Step 7. Record Points

Step 8. Move to next player, then advance to next level

---

In a nut shell there are 10 levels of cards 4 letters through 13 letters. The object of the game is to use as many letters as possible on your clue card to make a new word.

Scoring is based on how many letters from the clue word are used in the new word, excluding any added letters and how quickly the word was guessed.

Every round all players play with words of the same length, advancing to longer words at the beginning of every new round.

An example card:
4 letter
Knob : A small rounded handle

name: Doll House Game
description:
"Little girls will squeal with glee, as they advance their pieces from room to room on their way to the patio. Special added 'play it alone, all by yourself' feature provides and enjoyable single-player version. Complete with colorful gameboard, multi-colored die, pawns and rules for 1 or more players, Ages 4 - 8."

(description from Avalon Hill games catalog, 1963)

name: Coral Reef
description:
Build a calcareous masterpiece without noticing that you’re practicing addition with another marine polyp.

Object: To use all of your corals in building a reef.

You Need

* Two decks of poker cards, ideally with identical backs.
* Alternatively, you could use a bag of number tiles, like the ones available in the children’s section of department stores or a teachers’ supply store.

Take four nines from the deck and lay them out face-up as seeds for four stacks. Taking turns, each player attempts to get rid of all of his 'corals' (cards/tiles) by placing any number of corals on top of one stack such that the sum of the corals he places equals the number that had been on the top coral at the beginning of his turn. Corals are worth their pip value, except for face cards which are worth negative points.

The first one out of corals wins.

name: Maze
description:
Maze - A Maze Building Strategy Game For Two

The object of Maze is to construct a maze with as few tiles as possible, and to move your pawn through it from Start to Finish.

Each player starts with their Start/Finish tile on the table. Each turn, the player rolls a pair of dice. That player will then choose 2 out of the 3 options to perform, and allocates one of the rolled dice to each of those options. The options are:

Option 1: The player turns tile face up from a face down stack, until the number of face up tiles matches the number on the chosen die.

Option 2: The player chooses the number of tiles indicated by the die, and adds those tiles to their existing maze.

Option 3: The player advances their pawn through their maze as many squares (there are 2 squares per tile) as the die indicates.

The tiles have various configurations of bold lines around certain edges, indicating walls of the maze. When the maze is completed, it must be fully enclosed by the border, and all squares must be reachable by the pawn.

The round ends when a player has completed their maze and has moved the pawn from the Start to the Finish, entering Finish with an exact die roll. Alternatively, a round can end when both players have run out of tiles, and one of them has reached the end of their incomplete maze. Scores are tallied using various factors (number of squares in the maze, number of squares needed to complete the maze, number of squares the pawn needs to travel to reach the Finish, number of squares on unused face up tiles), and low score wins the round.

Rules are also included for variants to adjust the difficulty of the game.

(C) The Game Works, Inc. 1983

name: Spiromania
description: Spiromania is a quick paced action game for 2 to 4 players, ages 8 to adult. The object of the game is to "spiral" your playing pieces into the center home space. The uniqueness of Spiromania is the ability to sneak up on your opponents (by spiraling) to either block, pass or send them back to their starts.

name: JeuMok Plus
description:
The game consists of 24 solid pieces of wood 1x2x4 and a cloth bag that can contain them and has two different board printed on the two sides. A particular dice and another couple of cloth pieces are included.
The rules describe five different games, all for two players.
The first and most important (being quoted on the box) is a version of domineering with the variation that all the pieces must be placed adjacent to pieces previously played.
The second is a similar abstract strategy game with two separated starting "camps". The objective is to be the first to touch your opponent group of connected pieces.
The third game is also similar to domineering, but played on the board with smaller squares and using the dice. The dice dictates the spatial orientation in which the pieces must be played and the first unable to comply loses.
The fourth game is a sort of "Nim", while the last is a sort of "Jenga".

name: Chess Mutation
description: This is a Chess variant in which all pieces other than kings move and attack according to the space that they are resting upon. The board is marked with colours indicating each of the normal chess pieces (other than kings). Due to the board colouring, pieces initially act like the pieces that usually occupy their starting positions.

name: Festival Internacional de Cinema Fant√†stic de Sitges, The Game
description:
"Festival Internacional de Cinema Fantàstic de Sitges - The Game" is a game that represents the life during the Film Festival, with questions and answers about the Fantastic Film Festival and about the town of Sitges.

The Players, with a maximum number of 6, or in groups, have to move around Sitges, eat, sleep and go to the film sessions, with the object of seeing the most number of films.

The incidents of the game will take place on different squares and there will be questions to answer depending on the day an on the throw of the 3 die.

Components:
The Book of instructions and questions
A board representing the town of Sitges in the Festival area
6 Tokens one of each colour
12 food markers (two for each player)
24 sleep markers (four for each player)
6 passes to mark the answers (one for each player)
An assembled box to place the tokens and passes once they have been used
A Timing/List and squares included in the book.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: The Lincoln Challenge
description:
THE LINCOLN CHALLENGE is a monopoly style stock-market board game developed by the LINCOLN (UK) YMCA to generate funds for its activities. Lincoln is situated in the East of England and 120 miles above London

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company
(there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being
retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular
company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies.
This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:

After a set time
When the first player becomes bankrupt
When all but one player has gone bankrupt

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: The Race for the Cup
description: A roll-and-move racing game portraying the race for the America's Cup between the Columbia (USA) and Sir Thomas Lipton's Shamrock (UK). The board depicts a triangular yacht racing course.

name: The New Game of Virtue Rewarded and Vice Punished
description:
"For the amusement of youth of both sexes."

"Designed with a view to promoting progressive improvement of the juvenile mind, and to deter them from pursuing the dangerous paths of vice."

A roll-and-move race game where the players seek to travel from the house of corruption to reach virtue, the 33rd space on the board. Every space offers a punishment or reward, such as taking or losing tokens, going to a certain space, rolling again, etc.

The game board was a hand-colored engraving mounted in 12 sections on linen and stored in a slipcase. The game also included an 8-page rulebook.
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Blockade
description:
A game of luck and strategy for 2 players.

In early October
the Snoodles and Kleetches
all frolic and muddle
on kriddle-pop beaches.

Object: To get your pieces across the board and on to the other side before your opponent does.

You Need: A backgammon set.

Blockade is played on one-half of a Backgammon board, as divided by the Bar. The other half of the board is not used and can be folded under or used as a rolling surface for your dice. Each player starts the game with 16 pieces in six rows. Each row starts with three pieces in it, except the outside rows, which start with two. Each player's turn consists of the following steps: 1. Choose a row. 2. Roll a die. 3. Move pieces. The object is to 'leap' your pieces from your side of the board to the other player's side of the board and then to safety. The trick is that each die roll can only be used to move pieces on one row.

Play continues until all pieces controlled by a player have been removed from the board. The game ends immediately unless that player went first, in which case the other player gets one more turn to play. If the game ends with no pieces on the board, then the game is a draw. If one player has any pieces left on the board, then the other player wins.

name: Toss Words
description:
Components: 14 letter dice and a thick cardboard dice shaker.

"One, two, three, four, or more persons may participate in this game, singly or as partners. As you play you will find that this game provokes deep thought, and with each roll of the cubes your interest will mount."

Players take turns rolling the letter dice and forming words from the resulting letters. Words must have a minimum of 3 letters. Score one point for each letter used in forming words. Bonus: Use of all 14 letters counts 25, not 14. Bonus: The word "GAME" counts 50 points. There seem to be no penalties for unused letters.

Play to 100 or 200 points as agreed upon by the players. Doesn't say, however, how much time a player has per turn. Also, it seems that words are formed separately, not in crossword fashion.

Toss Words is a word dice game.

name: Yield!
description:
Your patrol vehicle materializes in Sector 701 of UrbanCube Nine, assigned to monitor for possible intrusion. If another vehicle appears in Sector 701, your mission is to immediately intercept and destroy it. The instant you deploy your sensors, red lights flash and klaxons howl: An intruder is already present! You grit your teeth and step on the accelerator...

Object: To demolish your opponent's vehicle while keeping yours intact.

You Need:

* A standard-sized chess- or checkerboard
* Two dice
* Two pawns or other markers
* Scrap paper (to keep track of damage)
* A set of 64 Yield! tiles (available for download on the game's website)

The board is made up of tiles that represent road sections. Players take turns laying tiles on the checkerboard until all the tiles have been played.

Gameplay consists of moving your pawn (your vehicle) around the board, attempting to collide with the other players under circumstances which will damage their vehicle and not yours. When you receive ten points of damage, you are out of the game. The last player remaining wins.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: The Crow
description:
You are a crow gathering Emotions for Draven to help him defeat Top Dollar. But while Sorrow, Pain, and Rage will overcome Top Dollar, it is the player with the most Love and Joy that will win.

Based on "The Crow" movie.

name: Black Rhino
description: Collect three of the same animal to get points.
publishers: AG M√ºller (AGM√ºller), ASS Altenburger Spielkarten, Rhino Games

name: Above the Clouds
description:
"Above the Clouds" was released as one of six in Milton Bradley's "Radio Series" of inexpensive race games costing 15 cents each. It debuted in the Bradley Games catalog of 1927 and was sold through 1933. A slightly larger but cheaper edition, at 10 cents, appeared in the 1943 catalog.

This is a simple spin and move game. It depicts a dirigible race. The board is a very simple track, which includes a few spaces where you get another turn or you have to move back. The first player to move his "balloon" the full length of the yellow route and back to the airdome wins the game.

name: Jack and the Beanstalk
description:
This game: JACK AND THE BEANSTOCK, from National Games Inc. of West Springfield Ma and numbered 406 has no date of publication but from the look of the box I would guess that mid 1940's would seem to be about right.

Each player selects a colored counter. First to start shakes the dice and goes the number of steps indicated by the sum of the spots on the dice. The next player takes a turn. If a counter lands on a yellow circle you must follow the directions printed close by (go back to a particulkar space or lose a turn or lose two turns or go ahead.) Two or more can be on the same step at the same time. First to reach the "end" wins the game.

name: Call It Golf
description: Call It Golf is a golf simulation that uses 6 spinners to represent the results of 6 types of clubs. The board is large & double sided. Chose your club, spin the spinner & plot the results on the board.

name: Cameo
description:
Partially based on a translation from Spielphase (see Web Links):

Cameo is a solitaire puzzle game.

The game board is a 8x8 grid. The grid itself is divided into four 4x4 areas of a different color. On each area four rectangular blocks of the same color as the area are placed.

The object is to move the blocks in such a way that each block is moved once and that at the end the areas contain blocks of a different color matching a previously chosen objective.

name: The Gold Medal World Olympian Game
description: Players try to capture as many of the Gold Medals as possible and obtain the most points to win.

name: 8 Second Madness
description:
Control the biggest and baddest bulls of the PBR! The goal is to shake off as many riders as possible while launching them at the scoreboard. Lay the board horizontal for beginners, or "Go Vertical" for an entirely different challenge! Let 'em fly individually, or add to the mayhem and everyone play at once! The first to successfully launch 8 riders gets bonus points! It's High Flyin' Fun!
It's 8 Second Madness!!
categories: Action / Dexterity, American West, Animals, Real-time, Sports

name: Ole Missopoly
description:
The Game Includes:

Tokens:
Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, Graduation Cap

Board Spaces:
The Grove, Holman Hall, Fulton Chapel, Daily Mississippian, Ole Miss Union, Four Corners, Dixie Week, Rebel Drive

Cards:
Recite the Fight Song or Lose One Turn.

Parking in Faculty Parking! Pay $50.

Graduation Fee! Pay $25 for each Year of Credit and $100 for each Diploma.

Ole Miss vs. LSU. Advance to Vaught-Hemingway Stadium. GO OLE MISS!

Red/Blue Weekend! Advance token of your choice to the space of your choice.

Enjoy the day at Sardis Lake. Pay each player $10 to borrow notes from class.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Hanging Monkies
description:
Players attempt to hang their monkeys from the tree as carefully as possible without causing it to collapse. The first player to successfully hang all of his monkeys is the winner. If the tree collapses the game is over and the players start again. This game contains rules for three different variations of the game: 1. Turn based with the use of a positive/negative numbered die, 2. Time based where all players move at the same time, 3. Team based where you can only hang your monkeys off of your teammate's monkeys. For ages 3 and up.

Similar to:

Monkey Business
Monkeying Around
publishers: Discovery Bay Games, Maple Toys, Pavilion

name: Barbie and the Magic of Pegasus
description:
A boardgame based on the Barbie movie Barbie and the Magic of Pegasus.

From the publisher: Help Annika and her sister, Brietta, break the evil wizard's spell that turned Brietta into a Pegasus and their family into stone! Race to collect the 3 items needed to build the Wand of light,then be the first to arrive back at the castle to rescue the royal family.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Flix Flax
description:
A Rock-Paper-Scissors like game played on a 3x3 board. Each player has 3 pieces (Red, Yellow, Green.) Each player secretly places his three pieces on his side of the board. After all of the pieces are placed, the players take turns moving his pieces around the board horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. The opponent's pieces can be captured by moving onto them either vertically or horizontally, but not diagonally. The object is to capture all of the opponent's pieces -- Green takes Red, Red takes Yellow, Yellow takes Green.

http://www.printgames.net/english/flix/detail_e.htm

name: The Wordmaster Game
description:
This game includes seventy two-sided cards printed with different crossword puzzle patterns. Players compete to score the most points while filling in the puzzles.

[note -- sorry this entry isn't more detailed; my copy is missing the instructions]

name: Clock Dominoes
description: 45 durable dominoes are included in this challenging game. It may be played at three levels of difficulty, covering hours, half hours, and quarter hours using clock faces, digital time, and written time. 1-4 players. Grades 2-6

name: Fraction Dominoes
description: Using 45 dominoes, players may play at 1of 3 levels of difficulty while adding fractions to find the sum of 1. Fractional parts are shown in pictorial and numerical form. It's a great activity for home and in learning centers.

name: Fourcast
description:
Four games of destiny: Taro reading, astrological casting, questions oracle, and numberology chart. Explore your past, present, and future. Fourcast combines four of the most respected occult methods of divination and fortune telling with games of skill and chance for your amusement and instruction.

Contents: 42 taro cards, six special instruction cards, astrology tally pad, numberology chart pad, fortune formula pad, oracle pendulum, answer board, and the instructions.

name: Battle to Baghdad
description:
From the Jiggi Games website:

"The US invasion of Iraq is now being played out all around the world. Jiggi Games has incorporated the events of the Iraq war into a reality board game.
Each player commands 3000 troops as you battle your way through Iraq. You will take out airports, night bomb cities, hunt down Saddam Hussein, and take over Baghdad...but look out!
This game is full of rebel attacks, car bombers, snipers, and other sorts of danger."

name: Tall Tales
description: Tall Tales is essentially a card game where players attempt to bluff the other players, with urban myths, legends, little-known-facts or their own stories.

name: Chokladsafari
description:
This is a promotional game made by Nordic chocolate company Cloetta. Board setup reminds you slightly of Talisman as players wander around outer regions collecting stuff before entering the middle area of the game. No fighting though.

Theme is to gather en expedition and then enter the jungle and transport cocoa to the harbor. A simple roll and move game, collect items (guide, provisions, tent, weapons, guide and pack horse), get trade goods (cocoa) and then get money for it. First player to a certain amount wins.

name: No Limite
description: Based on reality TV show "No Limite" (a kind of "Survivor"). Players are divided in two teams, trying to accomplish the tasks proposed.

name: Ham-N-Ex
description:
Pass the pigs with ham and eggs instead of pigs!

Throw the 'dice' (2 eggs (sunny side up) and 8 pieces of ham) to get valuable combinations like 'ham on eggs' or br'egg'fast.

name: In-Sekt-Surprise
description:
Game from the same series as e.g. Patron-Ow and Ham-N-Ex etc.

Start of each round a small bottle of champagne (without champagne of course...) and a bug each are hidden beneath one out of four miniature champagne coolers. Player chooses one cooler and turns it over - if it's the champagne or nothing he scores some points and may continue if he wants. If he finds the bug he gets negative points.

name: Hole in One: the Game
description:
A trivia roll and move board game......Object of the game: acquire the trivia tees(par,birdie and eagle) and have the lowest scoring round of golf.
Trivia tees categories:
Eagle: extremely difficult for pro players
Birdie:golf courses..rules,golf records etc..
Par: golf basics etc

name: Shmo
description:
"I'm a Shmo and that ain't good."

Each player is provided a "Shmo" marker (a plastic boy in short pants) which is placed onto an oversized board. Players roll the dice and move along a path containing such features as "Forgets his trousers...", "Takes wrong school bus..." or "Walks through wet cement." Each special feature directs the player to advance a number of spaces and pick a "Shmo card". The cards direct the player to perform some silly act and declare himself a shmo (Scratch your back 10 times and say, "I'm an itchy shmo!").

At the end of the path is a large box declaring: "First one here is a SHMO... ...and that ain't good!"

Shmo is a Tumblebum dice game, which is to say that the two dice are placed into an hourglass-shaped device (Tumblebum) which is spun around in order to roll the dice.

name: Ha Choo!
description:
Publisher's Description:

Ha Choo is an exciting new board game, designed to be both educational and fun, with the emphasis on fun! All players start out with fevers-the first one to reduce their fever back to normal with the proper ingredients is the winner! The excitement is generated in three ways: players collect playing cards, players reduce their fevers on their own thermometer by discarding cards, and players participate vocally when they land on special spaces! Ha Choo will teach the basic principles of good health and can reduce the worry and questions about first doctor's office visits.

Ages 4 and up, 2 to 4 Players"

All players start out with fevers-the first one to reduce their fever back to normal with the proper ingredients is the winner. Play is separated into three categories: players collect playing cards, players reduce their fevers on their own thermometer by discarding cards, and players participate vocally when they land on special spaces.

name: Terrific Toy Box
description:
The "Terrific Toy Box" card game was distributed by Target Stores in 1998. The cards depict various toys available at Target along with one card labeled "Empty Tox Box." The cards are essentially ads for toys (with brand names and logos displayed prominently).

Two games that can be played with the cards are described on the back of the package. The first, "Match the Toys," is simply blind Go Fish. Players take turns drawing cards from each others' hands in order to create matches in their own hands. The only card that cannot be matched is the Empty Toy Box card, and the player left holding this card is the loser.

The second game described on the package is "The Memory Game," in which players use the cards for a simple face down matching game.

name: The Adventures of Superman
description:
The object is to be the first player to move his Clark Kent piece from his starting corner into the "editorial sanctum" square at the center of the board.

Components: four different colored Clark Kent pawns, four Superman cloaks in corresponding colors, die, playing board, and two rules folders.

"Released less than two years after the very first appearance of SUPERMAN in ACTION COMICS #1 in 1938, this board game was initially sold in Macy's department stores in 1940." (Source: David T Alexander Collectibles)
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Transformers: Beast Wars
description: Japanese board game based on the Beast Wars TV cartoon and toy line in the Transformers Universe. From 1-4 players take the role of one of twelve different robots and race to accumulate power-ups and other bonuses before facing off against one another with the built-in "action roulette" wheel.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Au hasard de l'histoire
description:
Au Hasard de L'Histoire is a game retracing France's history from the Gaul tribes to the end of World War II.

Players will try to be the first to reach the end of the board by answering history questions of different types: facts, true or false, guessing the origin of an expression...

Some minor decisions must be made so as to manage your budget. Indeed the winner will not be the first one to reach the end of the board, but the one who has more currency (old coins, and bank notes) when everyone has reached the end.

name: Travel Australia Game
description:
A trivia game based on a map of Australia. Players roll 2 dice to move. If they land on a letter, they are asked a trivia question, with a correct answering advancing them and an incorrect answer sending them back. Cards earned at major cities confer other bonuses.

The game is aimed at the tourist market, and is sponsored by 40 Australian tourism companies. The board is the heaviest is my collection.

name: Dragon Lords
description:
Dragon Lords is an exciting and very different type of board game. Gather together with friends to build a fantasy landscape to both explore and wage war upon, all the time trying to gather to you a mighty army of conquest. No warlord though, can hope to win, unless they first raise and train a host of might dragons to soar across the skies, doing battle for their overlord and master. Dragon are the key to victory, for a mighty army, one that has taken you several turns to build, can be crushed by one encounter with one of your foe's mighty dragons.

Dragon Lords uses a unique card based system to create the playing area, and so each game is both different from the next, and a challenge, for players will need to lay down a path that will gain them access to the many special location that will allow then to possibly draw more dragon.

Heroes, magic and many options to customize your dragons await you as does the challenge of defeating your opponents in battle after battle, until only one survive to be declared the Dragon Lord.

The game comes with well over 350 2X2 inch cards, counters and a fully illustrated set of rule. Enjoy a night of bloody mayhem and adventure and player Dragon Lords.

Dragon Lords can be found at Bad Baby Productions, or bought online at RPGNow, the Edge.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Fantasy, Maze, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Biker Mice from Mars: Rock... 'N Ride! Card Game
description: In turn, players grab a card from the messy pile of cards and exchange it with one in their hand. Once a player has obtained 3 Biker Mice, 3 of their bikes, and 1 Lawrence Limburger Card, they win the round and move one space closer to Quigley Field. The first person to reach Quigley Field is the winner!

name: Bible Characters
description:
From the Publisher: "A popular form of Bible Study for the home, and profitable entertainment for social gatherings for young and old."

Consists of 33 cards, each featuring a character from the Bible. 4 clues on each card lead players to the correct character. The instructions include 9 play variants, including a version of charades.

name: Vulgarville
description:
Filled with naughty cartoons and dirty jokes, this wild party game will leave you in hysterics!

In Vulgarville, "worst is first". Your goal is to become the town's Mayor. This means bribing, stealing and back stabbing as you race to accumulate votes. Meet the hilarious town patrons, such as Chuck Chunks and Skidmark Rose. These patrons will vote for you throughout the game... if you can hold on to them!

name: Anastasia
description:
Also referred to as Rasputin's Revenge. This game was premium giveaway item to customers of Shell service stations to promote Twentieth Century Fox Film's theatrical release of their animated film, Anastasia. The game comes with the board folded into a triangular suitcase that holds plastic playing pieces of the movie's five main characters and a sheet that folds into a 6-sided die.

The object of the game is for players to safely arrive in Paris and defeat the evil Rasputin. They accomplish this by rolling the die to move ahead the indicated number of spaces. Players must then follow the directions on the space, if provided. To win, players must reach the last space and then be the first to make the correct die roll to destroy Rasputin.

name: Problems and Programmers
description:
Problems and Programmers is an educational software engineering card game. Featuring over 120 unique cards, it is intended to simulate the software development process from conception to completion. The game's players compete to finish their projects while avoiding the potential pitfalls of software engineering. These players will quickly learn that the strategies that will let them win the game are the same that will help them in the real world.

Complete rules, as well as files for creating all of the game components, previously could be found at http://www.problemsandprogrammers.com/

name: Bookie: The Card Game
description:
A betting game published by Central News Ltd.,London.

The game consisted of:
52 standard size playing cards,
6 horse "Runner" cards with seven numbers for
each named horse,
4 special set-up cards.

The description from the rules reads:
"The first horse to reach a position in line with the first card marking the course is the winner. The next horse to arrive achieves a "place" and wins one-third the odds offered by the Bookie...

Practice will quickly determine the possible odds to be laid.

These will range between 6 to 1 and 50 to 1, or possibly more."

name: Lil Squirt
description:
A children's dexterity game from the 1950s that is very similar to the game "Tickle Bee". The display is mounted on a yellow board and comes with a "magnetic skunk chaser".
A player must navigate the skunk through the simple maze under such red-colored objects as a ladder, a piper, a pig, a drum, a rock tunnel, a covered bridge, a haunted house, a drain pipe, or an old stump. However, one should be careful to not to get too close, or the skunk will "spray" (lift up off the board and touch the wand).

"Lil Squirt likes to run and play but don't get too close, or he will spray."

name: Tempputorni
description: In Tempputorni (=Tricktower) players enter different rooms in the tower. In each room there are inhabitants of the tower who make players do different physical tasks.

name: Mawari-Sugoroku
description:
E-Sugoroku or Picture Sugoroku is Japan's version of the roll-and-move race game. This entry in the BGG database serves for the myriad versions and themes used in E-Sugoroku, which include religion, travel, theater and more.
The earliest mentions of E-Sugoroku are of Pure Land Sugoroku, where the objective of the game is to reach the Pure Land, the Buddhist Western paradise. In the 17th Century, E-Sugoroku became popular with beautiful art on boards depicting the journey from Kyoto to Edo, or scenes of famous Kabuki actors. A second wave of popularity occurred in the 19th Century, after the Meiji Restoration, at which time it also became more of a children's game. Today, E-Sugoroku sets feature contemporary themes and can be found in toy-stores and 100-yen shops.
A feature of E-Sugoroku is that dice rolls do not always translate into the same number of steps. Instead, progress from one step to the next could be made only by rolling specific numbers, or different numbers could indicate different paths to be taken.
E-Sugoroku should be distinguished from Ban-Sugoroku (BGG entry at Sugoroku), a game with an earlier origin and which is more akin to Backgammon. The generic term Sugoroku literally means 'double six' and is applied to board games that use dice.

Reference: Masukawa Koichi, Scenic Views: E-Sugoroku. In: Asian Games: The Art of Contest. Asia Society, 2004.

name: INC.  The Game of Business
description: You are the CEO of a large corporation. During the course of the game, you buy and absorb small businesses into your corporation. You also work to acquire enough employees to fully staff all of your businesses. You can occasionally swap stock and businesses with other players. In addition, you can steal employees from them. The goal is to have $1 million in cash and have your corporation fully employed.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Dino-War
description: This is a proprietary take on the classic children's game War. The game is played with a unique 36 card deck with three cards in each of 12 ranks, each represented by a different dinosaur. The game is played until one player has possession of all of the cards.

name: Stork Bingo
description: Bingo game with words that pertain to baby such as "rattle" and "teething ring" Each Stork Bingo game comes complete with 16 cards, markers and a caller's board.

name: Sportfiskespelet
description: Answer questions about fishing, if you get the answers right you get fishing-tackle to use when you move around the different fishing sites and try your luck.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ett skepp kommer lastat
description:
This is a word game where there are 25 squares on the board and the idea is to fill them with colored tokens. The squares show different topics such as birds, countries or fruits. The player spins on a wheel with letters and the letter that the spinner stops on should be the initial letter of the word you are competing for. When you come up with a word you say it aloud and throw a small ball into the box. If there are more players who says a word at the same time, it is the ball that comes at the bottom that wins. For each win you have to mark the box and the one that first succeeds in marking 10 squares or most if all 25 squares are marked wins.

The name of the game translates into English as 'The ship is loaded'.

name: Kellogg's Pro Soccer
description:
From the rules page:

"If you don't know or understand soccer, this game will teach you. If you do know soccer, this game will be a challenge to your knowledge and ability."

This is a one-page insert that came with a Kellogg's product (pop-tarts, I believe) and, despite the name of the publisher, is not a computer game. Play results are determined by drawing cards from a standard deck of cards, instead of using dice.

This is just one in a series of about 6 sports games distributed this way.

name: Are You Phrazy? TV Edition
description:
The TV edition of Are You Phrazy.

Players make witty conversation in an attempt to be the first player to get rid of all their cards.

All the cards have famous phrases from TV shows.

Green cards are used to start the conversation("Da Plane! Da Plane!) Yellow to keep the conversation going("Who loves ya baby!") Red to stop the conversation("Good night, John boy").

Players with the same card that was just played, may jump in and play out of turn.

name: My First Word Game
description:
An introduction to simple vocabulary words.

Children learn which words go with which picture. The puzzle pieces are self-correcting & the various games suit different age-appropriate stages for fun while learning.

Players: 1 - 4 Playing

Time: 20 minutes

Ages: 4 and up

From the Spelling & Math Games Department.

This is a different version than the "My First Words" edition which sometimes shares the same name, focusing on words used in a train station, a construction site, an airport and a traffic intersection.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Puzzle, Word Game

name: Memorandum
description: There are 30 cards, a normal six-sided die, a color die and a gameboard. The players are aiming at collecting 5 cards for themselves by remembering the letters on the top cards of stacks.

name: The Xenon Empire's Star Wars: Crusade Against the War-Lords
description:
The Xenon Empire's Star Wars was one of the titles in Galaxy-Foundation Games' strategic Battle for Andromeda: Conflict for a Trillion Suns! series. The games in this series used a series rulebook which contained the production rules, ship information, movement and combat rules, etc., and a game-specific rulebook describing the scenario, units, and special rules.

This particular game covers a war between the Xenon Empire and the Federation of the Monad. From a GFG catalog (reproduced verbatim, but with some sections removed):


STAR WARS OF THE XENON EMPIRE: Crusade against the Warlords. Connected to the Deliverance Game, this is also a game in itself. IT has the most unique feature, as every BFA game has a new feature incorporating a special principles from others. THIS IS THE ONLY GAME THAT CAN BE PLAYED SOLITAIRE in its fullest sense. Yet, it is designed for "LIVE" play with one or two additional players. Many Gamers not having partners often play by themselves, but the Paper-Computer set-up to function alone or with two players allows unique and individual actions!




Xenon has a vital Colony off the board (on another map in another Game). This Colony may be struck by the Kons Dirak Ahm, the oppressive Empire of such huge size and tyrannical rule that all independent Cultures fear it. Only the numerous revolts needing reprisals and other Cultures being overrun have prevented the Xenon Cluster-Colonies from being brought to heel. Xenon needs to consolidate its own systems before attempting to aid their Colonies, yet their Vast Cluster System is surrounded by the War-Lords - small petty Groups that of themselves have little power, but nibble away at Xenon Zones. To wipe them out is easy, but time-consuming.




[deleted for space]




The Monads, using the deadly Monadian "web", a Plasma Body of sheer energy that drains and implodes ships and holds fleets in submission. The Xenon Vulcan Cannon and their "Harpoon" Missile Conglomerates (each one as big as Cuba or Florida!), and a variety of other weapons such as Diffusion Mines, Sabre Beams, Phasers, Photon Torpedoes, and even the Death Ray of Doom!




The entire Xenon Fleet is enclosed, as well as the Monads' strange ships and the Warlord forces, but over 30 Tactical-Variant Cards, play aids, and Scenario Manual. No two games or Strategies can ever be alike! The 22x28-inch rigid Map-Board predominates in Brilliant Reds and "hot" pinks - a startling appearance once observed by new players.

name: Urheilu tietopeli
description: Sports trivia game published in Finland to celebrate the summer Olympic Games in Atlanta. The board represents an athletics stadium that players are "running" around.

name: Das rote Nashorn
description:
The German show-host Wim Thoelke presented this game about an African safari. People rolling around a track trying to get pictures of the animals.
Near the end there are several spots occupied by a red rhinoceros (hence the name of the game). If a player lands there, he loses all animals and has to start from the beginning.
categories: Adventure, Animals, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Quest for Clients
description: Quest for Clients is developed and produced by Identity Games for Capgemini. It is a Monopoly-like game, where each 'street' is a client, and the players are competing consultants, who try to win the game by offering more service to clients, and trying to keep other consultants away from clients.

name: Bambukarhut
description: Bamboo bears known from TV are here. Join Bamboo-Lee, Slo-Lee and Dah-Lin for an adventure. If you're lucky you're traveling fast on the back of the dragon Ai-Ai. If you're not so lucky the Rats appear and try to slow you down. Players are traveling around the world and saving endangered species. The game teaches kids ecology and they can learn about endangered species.

name: Don't Drink and Drive
description:
From the designer's website...

So you've been out drinking all night, now it's time to go home. The object of the game is to make it home safe (call a cab). You must drive your car all around the board to the end where home is. On your journey you will encounter some real wacky stuff, laughing your ass off the whole time. You might stop off at another bar or stop for some fast food. You might be able to call a cab to drive you home (that's the plan). You better hope you get a chance to call a cab because there are police cars all over the board waiting to pull over DRUNK DRIVERS.

If your car lands on one of these spaces you must take a sobriety test (30 different tests, tongue twisters, memory tests, physical challenges, etc...), if you fail, you get a DWI and will find yourself in JAIL.

There are over 100 spaces on the board (exploding with exceptional artwork and design) telling you to do all sorts of crazy things. The game can be different every time you play it. You can rear-end people, cut each other off the road and even get into an accident, 3 accidents and/or 3 DWI's and your out of the game. You can also take a different route the next time you play, there are forks in the roads so you can go two different ways, the long route or the short route, which way will you be going? Who knows what's going to happen to you on your way home.

So call a cab and stay out of jail. The players in the cabs usually make it home before anyone, thus being the winner.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Educational, Humor, Party Game

name: Les Prodiges du Sport
description:
A sports trivia game published in Quebec in 1988. The marketing of this game used heavily the name and image of ex-NHL all-stars player Guy Lafleur. His picture appears on the box cover and on the board, and a letter signed by him is in the box. Another sheet invites people to write in to become a game-club member, in order to get souvenirs and a signed photo.

Communications SportStar inc., the publisher of this game, were also TV producers of Hockey-related television programming. The game itself was released to publicize a sports trivia TV show of the same name, then in development, that would have been co-hosted by Guy Lafleur. The show was never produced.

The game is a standard trivia game, with questions in 5 categories: Hockey, Baseball, Football, Olympic sports, and miscellaneous.

The game is played in two phases. Starting on the inner ring, the player can go in a direction of their choice the number of spaces indicated by their die roll, in order to accumulate 150 points. In the first phase, a player may choose to move to the outer ring. Once they have reached 150, a player will attempt to answer the most consecutive questions in each of the five sides of the outer ring, one per category. Missing a question forces the player to leave that side. A completed side is worth 40 points. The first player to accumulate a total of 350 points wins the game and is named "Prodige du Sport" (i.e. "Sports Prodigy").

name: Funny Face
description:
The object of the game is to complete a funny clown face before any other player. the first player to complete a funny face wins the game.

Each player selects a clown. each clown has 7 removable pieces (2 ears, 2 eyes, nose, mouth and bow tie). take your FUNNY FACE clown apart by pushing the die cut pieces from beneath. Place all the pieces in the center of the table. each player spins the spinner in turn and takes the piece the spinner points to. If he already has such a piece he must wait for his next turn.

The 7 pieces are interchangeable in all the funny faces, and each player makes the funniest face possible.

Similar to:

Jumbolino
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Puzzle, Racing
mechanics: Memory, Modular Board, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Fridge Horse Racing
description:
This is one in a series of magnetic games designed to be played on your refrigerator (or file cabinet at work, or any other metallic surface).

This is a steeple jump horse racing game, with magnetic racetrack and 2D horses.

The odds vary with each horse, and a spinner is used to determine speed as well as to discover how successfully a horse executed a jump.

The game may be played face to face, or over the course of time, utilizing a Your turn square. Take your turn, flip the square so that your opponent's color is on top, signifying that it's his turn, then walk away. When your opponent sees that he's up, he can stop, play out his turn, flip the square, and go on about his business.

This feature justifies the magnetic aspect of the game. It can be set up indefinitely and be played out as quickly or as slowly as you desire. This makes it suitable for home or office play when you don't have time to sit down and play an entire game start to finish.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Shocking Memory
description:
Similar to the game Simon, Shocking Memory has eight panels instead of four and you get shocked if you make a mistake. This game is not intended for small children or persons with heart conditions.

From the publisher's website:
Put your memory to the test. Repeat the sequence of lights and sounds. Each round gets a little longer and harder. If you can't remember the sequence; thats too bad, we're so sad...ouch! With three speeds even the best players will be sweating.

name: Count Dino's Number Marathon
description: Each player tries to move his herd of dinosaurs across the finish line first by rolling dice and counting. A player chooses a herd (all Stegasauruses or Dimetrodons or T. Rexes or Triceratops, etc. Each dinosaur in a herd is a different color: red, yellow, green, and purple. A player rolls four dice and puts them in any order he wishes so that they make a four-digit number. Then he moves each dinosaur along a separate colored path: the red dinosaur moves by the thousands digits, the yellow dinosaur moves by the hundreds digits, and so on. Then the next herd of dinosaurs starts their trek on the path to the finish line. Game variations allow for showdowns, "Dino Math Action," and "Prehistoric Problem Solving" for older children.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Professor Noggin's Insects and Spiders
description:
Insects and Spiders are some of nature’s tiniest wonders. Learn what they eat, where they live, and what makes them unique in this creepy, crawly Professor Noggin game that is guaranteed to keep you swarming with excitement.

Card.topics.include:
Ants
Black Widow Spider
Dangerous Insects
Dragonflies
Earthworms
Earwigs
Firefly
Fleas
Flies
General Topic Card
General_Topic_Card_2
Honey Bees
Insect Anatomy
Jumping Spiders
Ladybug
Monarch
Mosquitos
Moths
Northern Walkingstick
Pets and Plagues
Praying Mantis
Spiders
Stink Bugs
Treehoppers
Water Strider
Weird Insects
Whirligig
Wolf Spiders
Wood Lice
Woolly Bear Caterpillar
categories: Animals, Card Game, Educational, Environmental, Trivia

name: Spider and the Fly
description:
Spider and the Fly Whitman Publishing # 4720 "Another Whitman Fun-Planned Game"
Player 1 plays a spider with a trapping cup. Player 2 plays two flies. The Spider shakes the dice in the spider cup, turns cup upside down in the center of the web, and lifts the cup. If both dice are even numbers, he tries to trap the Fly on the right with the cup before the player controlling the fly can pull the fly off the board with its attached string. Odd numbers activate the leftmost fly. One even / one odd die ... free parking.
Comes with two flies on strings, two scoring pegs, two wooden dice and a small bowl with a spider molded onto it.

Bears some resemblance to the game Pounce!

name: Ultima Generation: Road to the Avatar TCG
description:
Collectible Card Game based on the "Ultima Online" game world, which licensed by Electronic Arts.

In the game of Ultima Generation, players become one of the lords in Britannia. The main casting factors in the game are eight virtues as in Ultima - Spirituality, Honor, Compassion, Valor, Justice, Honesty, Sacrifice, and Humility. Good lord summons adventures with positive virtues and summoning monsters costs virtues or minus virtue status for evil lord. Lord who defends her territory and controls the eight virtues wins the competition.

name: H√ºhnerjagd
description: In this game your current home is a chicken coop. You are a chicken and want your freedom. Your fellow players - who are also chickens - are also looking to escape. Your only money is chicken fodder you have saved. And the farmer knows your plans to escape and will try to defeat them! Will you be able to get out?

name: MoneyPower
description:
Roll the dice and move around the board. Land in certain areas to buy and/or sell investments. Other areas also allow trading and selling of investments to other players. Also, you can purchase investment chips.

Although this is an investment strategy game, the person with the most money is not the winner. The first person to have ten chips is the winner.

name: Island Hopping
description:
Island Hopping is how you get around in The Bahamas! And it's also a lively game of strategy and chance. As you play, you'll explore the country's beautiful islands and discover places you'd like to go.

You win the game by stacking four similar coins on one island. But as you develop your winning strategy, remember that your best-laid plans can be sidetracked as the game takes you to unexpected destinations!
mechanics: Hand Management, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Nobel
description: Nobel is a world peace game. The goal is simple. Achieve world peace. In order to succeed, players must disarm all the countries featured on Nobel's map of the world. The winner is the player who has gathered the most world peace doves at the game's end. He received the Nobel Peace Prize of the world Peace Game. All things considered, the game is about missiles, disarmament and world peace treaties.
publishers: Richard Maroist Toys and Games, Inc.

name: BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal
description: A stand alone BWAH!! game that can be combined with the original if desired. BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal is based on the game BANG!! but set in the "Firefly" universe created by Joss Whedon. This one is based on the movie "Serenity" and not directly the show. The game uses the same mechanics as BWAH! and BANG! except the characters and professions are from the movie. Some examples are Wash, Zoe, and Mal as characters and Psychic, Crew, Captain, Reavers, and Operative as professions. Health is recovered by eating Fruity Oaty Bars.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Curious George A B See Game
description: In Curious George A B See Game, four cards playing cards are set in front of the players. The cards are double sided and contain either: (1) different colored letters of the alphabet or (2) different colored objects (purple zebra, green triangle, etc.). A color and letter card are simultaneously flipped over. The players must quickly find either a letter that is in the correct color or an object in the correct color that begins with the chosen letter. If you are the first to identify the combination, you get the letter card. Any player that makes a misidentification loses a card already won. After all 26 letters have been played, the winner is the player with the most cards.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Real-time

name: Elimination 3
description: A two player derivative of the Morris family of games, which can be played with partners. The object of the game is to get three pegs in a row on either the solid or dotted lines. Each time you do so, you get to remove an opponents piece. The game ends when either you opponent concedes or has only two pegs left.

name: Pavement Pals Activity Book & Chalk
description:
This is nothing more than a book outlining 14 outdoor activities (including several games) that can be played with the included sidewalk chalk (in 6 colors, hence the suggested maximum number of players in this entry).

Some games are no-brainers (Hopscotch, Tic-Tac-Toe) others are a bit unusual (drawing a race track and alternately flicking chalk to draw lines of advancement around the track).

Essentially, it's a structured set of sidewalk chalk.

name: Media Mogul
description:
Build your media empire!

The Media Mogul owns all of the assets in one of the 6 Markets.

Invest in real media assets by blind bidding against other players. You'll need a range of TV channels, radio and magazines, to corner one of the 6 Markets themed by content eg. fashion, arts, mens', music

It's a bit like poker - with lots of emotion raising eye contact etc and the thrill of gambling. And it is cool buying up MTV, Channel 4 and Hello! no matter how much of an anti-media guru you are...
categories: Economic, Negotiation, Party Game, Territory Building
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Stock Holding

name: Skittle Tac-Toe
description: Skittle Tac-Toe by Aurora. Just like Tic-Tac-Toe - with a skittle shooter.

name: Malaya
description:
Summary from the box:
From the Founding of Melaka to the Road to Independence, journey through Malaysia's History in this exciting and educationally stimulating game.
Journey through Malaysia's History...
