Every player tries to bring his pawn to the finish line as soon as possible. You may move your pawn whenever you manage to guess one of the four answers the opponent team will give to a funny situation, located on the game cards. Who has the best knowledge of the human nature?

name: Mampf!
description:
A fun game about fast food.
Players try to eat at the worst fast food joint in town: "Dieter's Grill Express". But before they can do this, they have to prove that they can produce and digest the greasiest fast food.
On your turn, you throw the dice and move that number of spaces.
If you land on a grey space, every other player but you has to eat at your fast food joint: on a menu table, fast food is selected via a d20 roll. This culinary sensation has now to be digested: the table gives a health number, added is a d6 roll, the player's experience level and various modifiers from cards. If the modified result is higher than that health number, the player gains experience. If he rolls lower, he is taken to the hospital and misses his next turn.
The more experience the players gather, the harder will the menue tables become, but to win, you have to collect at least 30 points to finally eat at "Dieter's" and win the game.
Other spaces help players on their quest, like "Restaurant" where you can eat proper food and gain more health (aka die roll modifiers), "Doctor" where you can avoid the next hospital result, or "Toilet", where you can get all that grease out of your system and increase your health number.

name: Das Testament des Gottfried von Bouillon
description:
An adventure game where players try to find a legendary wine barrel in the ruins of a castle. The game is based on the adventure comic with the same name from Yves Chaland. Each player represents a character from that comic.
On your turn, you roll the dice and move that number of spaces. The space you land is either blank (and the next player takes his turn); it on contains an event (like miss one turn, roll the die and move that more spaces, pay a fine, etc.); or it contains a color and a symbol. In the latter case, the player consults his character booklet and looks up the page with the corresponding color and symbol. A short story there is read and and the player has to decide what to do next: the booklet gives two or more choices and each choice corresponds to a numbered paragraph in the rule book, which is looked up and carried out.
These paragraphs are the heart of the game and the key to victory. The rule book also suggests that you read the comic book to understand the game and the story better.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Ready Steady Fart
description:
Ready Steady Fart is a memory game similar to an old parlor game sometimes known as "My Grandmother's Trunk." Players take turns adding items to a list in alphabetical order, and attempting to remember the entirety of the list as it gets longer.

Ready Steady Fart, however, also contains a deck of cards that force the players to make changes to the alphabetical recipe, the prologue, or the order of play in midstream, making it even more difficult than the parlor game.

The fart theme appears to be something of an afterthought, and has little to do with the actual game play.
publishers: McNaughty Games, Paul Lamond Games Ltd

name: Euro 2008 Giga Quiz Fussball
description:
A small trivia game with 36 trivia cards á 7 questions. Question 1 is supposed to be 'easy' while 7 is 'very hard'. The questions all center around soccer, some are specific about the Euro 2008 in Austria/Switzerland.

The player on turn selects a difficulty level (1 to 7) and a card is drawn. If he answers the chosen question correctly, that's his score and the next player takes his turn. After the draw pile is exhausted, the scores are added and the winner is the player with the highest score.

name: Music Frenzy: The Music Game
description:
The object of the game is to get to the "Fine" from the "D.C." first by answering as many theory questions as possible.

Roll the dice and move that many spaces and follow the instructions on the board.

name: Grappler I
description: Grappler I is a strategy based Greco Roman wrestling game with high school and college variants. Each player, using a set of 20 Outcome Sheets (cards) for "Home" (green) and "Visitor" (red), determine the results of takedowns, reverses, escapes, and controls by rolling his/her five D6s. As points are awarded, players track the match using a separate "time" scoring pad. Each game can be ran as a team match or a tournament for individual weight classes.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Peter and the Wolf
description:
44 cards telling the story of Peter and the Wolf in the Disney film "Make Mine Music".
Players have to get rid of their cards as soon as possible whilst laying down as many sequences as they can during the game.The cards are described as four character cards and eight 'reels' of five cards each.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music

name: Guiding
description:
After the Scouts got a game in 1955, now the Guides get a game.
44 cards. The game is won by the first player to play out a set of 10 cards and the First Class Badge, 11 cards in all.
A game related to Rummy type games but you don't lay down sets or sequences, you lay one card a turn, adding to the length of the sequence started by you.. Players draw a card and, if they have a 1, they must lay it in front of them. Having play a 1, they are now 'looking' for a 2, and so on. If you lay down 10 cards eventually, you only need to add a First Class Badge card (which represents an 11 in your sequence), to win the game.

name: Wild Flower Sevens
description:
Another Pepys game that was inspired by a traditional card game (Sevens). Brilliant work by the artist.
44 cards in four suits of eleven cards, numbered 2 to 12.
Play begins when somebody lays down a 7 and places it in the centre of the table. The next player must lay down another 7, or he can add an eight or a six (of the same suit) either side of the original 7, and so on. If he cannot play a card, then he has to pass.
Players aim to play all the cards in their hand and to be the first to do so.

name: The Jungle Book
description:
A game released because of the Disney cartoon.
44 cards in four sets of eleven cards. Players have to form runs or sets (as in Rummy). The game ends when six hands have been played or at the end of any hand when a score of 100 or more is achieved.
The cards are illustrated with characters and scenes from the film.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: De Helden van onze Planeet
description:
De Helden van onze Planeet is a card game in which players try to reach the number 2020 first, because 2020 is the year that WWF has set as goal to live in harmony with nature.

Players start in the year 0 and try to be the first to reach the year 2020 by playing out cards with numbers. These numbers represent years and players have to reach year 2020 exactly! There are of course special cards to block another player, steal years from another player, or play extra cards. The cards itself have photos and information on them about nature, wildlife, and preservation of the environment. So besides the game-play there is a learning factor for children.

name: Rupert
description:
A children's card game, rather like Memory, where you have to win pairs of cards. Complete luck at first but as more cards are revealed (and then placed back face-down), memory comes into the game. An easier version for very young children is also provided. The company also suggest that Snap could be played with the same cards.
44 cards, illustrated with characters from the Rupert comic strip and the Rupert Annuals that appeared every year.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Memory
publishers: Gibsons, Pepys (Castell Brothers), TJ & J Smith Limited

name: Home Cricket
description: The board is made up of 144 squares, each with either a number (the runs scored with that delivery) or a way of getting out. Each set of six squares is labelled with an over. You start in the first over and end with the 24th over. Players throw a die and move along the row labelled with the first over and check the result. Now the marker is moved back to the start of that over and a die is thrown again, and so on for six deliveries. Then it is the 2nd over, and so on. The publisher thought that it would be a good idea to say it was a game for more than the obvious two players. So three can play (two pair up against the other single player), or four (both teams consist of a pair of players) or five players (two teams of two players and the fifth player just acts as scorer and he gets to shout "Over" at the end of each six deliveries.

name: I Spy
description:
A 1948 board game by the card game specialists, Pepys.
One player is the Spider and the other players are Flies. Inspired by Ludo, Flies have to get 'home' whilst the Spider must capture 5 Flies before any one Fly player gets all his Flies safely home.

name: Maximum Break
description:
A Snooker-based game that needed to be 'made' by any interested gamer. It was self-published in a fanzine from the mid-eighties.

Cards provide a variety of options open to a Snooker player when he comes to the table. When a player takes on a pot, cards are used to generate three decisions. The first card drawn will tell if the shot is Easy, Medium or Hard. The next card will give you the first digit of a two-digit number between 01 and 99. And the third card completes the number. Numerous charts and tables are required for the game.

The rules allow for special events - a Foul Shot, a snooker, Bad Kicks, Getting out of a snooker and a choice of playing safely or riskily.

name: Ein, Zwei, Drei
description:
A partnership card game, played with traditional playing cards.
Each player is dealt 13 cards but only 12 tricks are played for. The 13th card is used at the start to give to your partner. This should indicate how many tricks you think you can win. The card will be used later in the game. Tricks are won by playing 1, 2 or 3 cards. 1 card played is just a normal trick as in Bridge or Whist, but there are specific rules about what constitutes a trick playing 2 or 3 cards.
100 points equals a game. Before play begins, players decide on a 'best of' five, say, i.e. the first pair to score three games would be the winner.

name: Spello
description:
The gameboard is a nineteen-by-nineteen grid with the corners missing; the first and last rows and columns are elongated. In this elongated spaces, players may place more than one letter to make their words.

From a pool of letters, the players determine which letters will be randomly added to their hands. The players, in turn, add their letters to the grid to make words in crossword fashion.

The game contains one sheet or rules and nineteen games printed in ten sheets of paper. The game is consistent with Robert Mansfield’s packaging that allows a complete set to be stuffed into a standard business envelope.

name: Times Seven: Creation
description:
"Challenge your memory and test your luck as you race to collect seven Bible verses over seven rounds and win the game!
Learn what the Bible says about the creation as you lay down one completed verse per hand. Then discard key words from the verses to outscore your opponents. If you can't complete the verse before the round ends, you must try, try again!"

Each round, players attempt to collect a set of four numbered, color coded cards that complete a Bible verse. This is done by drafting and discarding. Once a complete verse has been collected the player then lays down their set and tries to go out as soon as possible by discarding their remaining cards on other players' sets. Keyword cards and other action cards add an extra twist to the gameplay. At the end of each round, points are 'awarded' based on remaining cards-in-hand, and after seven rounds the lowest scorer wins!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Religious
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Gamate
description:
This game is for 4 players, playing as partners.

Each card has a value from 1 to 48. The four Aces are excluded from this and are called Muettes (the French word for Mute). Each player can bid which is really a search for a trump sequence. An example of bidding could be 'All the red cards' or '7s to 9s'. The only restriction in the bidding is that a legal bid must be at least 2 cards and no more than 24 cards. Once established, the hand is played. Note that there is no following suit, you can play any card in your hand to a trick and that the partnership, that won the bid, can nominate that each trick will be played High or Low (all tricks will be won by the highest ranked card or that each trick will be won by the lowest ranked card).
I understand that one year after the release of the game, the author published a revised set of rules which customers could collect at their Parisian game's shop.

name: Europa im Jet
description: Educational game for children. They fly across Europe and learn a little geography. The winner is the first player who has visited the airports and also answer a question about each city.

name: High Stakes Party Football
description:
Each player picks a game piece and place it on its image on the board. High roll of dice determines who goes first.
Set up Freddie, decide whether to play for real cash or play stuff, pace your ante. Turn on TV football game - It's party time!

Object of the Game: You are betting on a football game so if you win the money, ah...you win! Game play is determined by the TV game. Make first downs and win the Freddie Pot in the middle of the field. Make it to the end or be the farthest along the board or game's end to win the big bucks in the Pom Pot in the end zone! Game Contents: 8 playing pieces and stands, Freddie Football and stand, pair of dice, play money, game board and rules sheet

Components:

1 game board.
8 playing pieces and stands.
Freddie Football with stand.
Pair of dice.
Play money (80 1s, 5s and 10s).
Rules sheet.

name: Racing Cars
description:
GoPlay racing cars mini magnetic travel game set.
Usual roll and move game with spinner. Player who finishes first is the winner.

Components:

spinner,
12 counters,
1 tin box clip

name: PongCano: The Game of Sacrifice
description:
PongCano is a simple-to-learn, easy-to-play tabletop game for all skill levels. The task is simple - bounce the ball into the PongCano volcano and be the last player with all the chips. The longer a game plays, the better each player gets (hopefully) and the higher the stakes rise for each shot. Players must control their nerves and hold their laughter until the ball lands safely in the bottom of the PongCano volcano. Make a shot and the pressure is off for a short time; miss a shot and sacrifice a chip into the PongCano volcano.

AND guess what? No player is ever out of the game! Even if all your chips are lost you can make one great shot that will have you sitting behind a new stack of chips in victory!

name: kaleidoshape
description:
Contents:
-Boardgame with central turntable
-48 geometrical shapes matching the shapes on the board
-4 bingo cards
-rolling die and marker

+ additional picture cards to play a variant

This is bingo game with colors and shapes instead of numbers. Children throw the dice and move the turntable the same number of spaces as shown in the dice. As a resutl shapes matching those on the bingo cards are formed and the children can pick those.
Excellent to develop color and shape recognition.

name: Wrangler Heritage Quiz Card Game
description:
Advertising-related game, for Wrangler jeans, etc.
Questions test your knowldge within the years 1945 to 1985. Players score penalty points for wrong answers and the player with the least amount of penalty points after the deck has been used completely, wins.

From the packet:

"Test your knowledge of Britain with this compulsive new card game, quiz and puzzle combined.

Inside this pack are 50 cards - 48 ask the questions, 2 cards give the answers (in case you are really stuck!)

A rules leaflet tells you how to play.

There are two games to play, with up to 5 of your friends, and two games to play on your own."

This game is a fairly straightforward quiz with a color photograph on each card to illustrate the location concerned in the question. The method for answering is quite novel. Instead of a straight a) b) c) d) multiple choice, you pick your answer and go to the next card according to the number next to that answer. You should find that your set of answers takes you back to your starting card after eight questions.

There is interaction between the players when one person thinks they need a cards already used by another in their answer. There is then a challenge for the card because each card can only appear in a single set of answers.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music, Sports, Trivia

name: Jack and Jill (A first card game)
description:
A simple card game for pre-school youngsters.The cards depict characters or scenes from the nursery rhyme 'Jack and Jill went up the hill'. You just draw a card, if it is Jack you place it in front of you. If it isn't Jack you discard it. Once you have Jack, you need to draw Jill, and so on. The cards must be collected in this order; Jack - Jill - Jack and Jill going up the hill - Jack and Jill fetching a pail of water - Jack falling down and Jill tumbling after - Jack in bed with his head bandaged with vinegar and brown paper.
The first player to collect these cards in that order, wins.

name: S.O.S. Sink or Swim
description: 48 cards, 16 with a number on them (1,2,3 or 4) and the other cards are illustrations of flora and fauna. The numbered cards are all examples of what not to do in the country. I do not have the rules sadly but an educated guess is that it is a game related to Beat Your Neighbors, the traditional children's card game. The cards are dealt equally amongst the players. In his turn, a player turns over one card. If it does not have a number on it, the next player turns over a card, and so on. If a numbered card appears, the next player must turn over cards equal to that number. If that player turns over a number when doing this, the next player must turn over cards. If no number is turned over when 'paying the penalty', the person who played the number collects all the cards and puts them at the bottom of his stack. The winner is the one who has captured all the cards.

name: World Weddings
description:
52 cards in 13 sets of four. They are all illustrated with characters from a specific country and they consist of, for example, Mr America, Miss America (both in colour) and a Mr America and a Miss America (not in colour). The object is to win tricks by the pairing of two cards relating to the same country. The pairs maybe a wedding pair, a pair of spinsters or a pair of bachelors. Each pair has a value in points. A 'Society' Wedding (the two coloured cards of a country scores 5 points. A 'Quiet' Wedding (The two non-coloured cards of a country or one with colour and one without) scores 3 points. A Pair of Spinsters or Pair of Bachelors (from the same country) scores 1 point. If you can collect all four cards from a country, you can score bonus points; Two Society Wedding Pairs 15 points; Two Wedding Pairs - no Society Wedding 10 points; Pair of Spinsters and a Pair of Bachelors 6 points.
The game play is interesting. Players draw a card and place it to start to form rows of cards face-up. Five such cards are permitted in a row. If two cards from the same country 'touch' each other (vertically, horizentally or diagonal) then that pair is taken by the player. If a pair is taken the remaining cards are moved to the left of their row. If a card reaches the left end of a row and needs to be moved it is added to the right end of the row above.
Play several hands and the first player to reach 100 points is the winner.
A solitaire variant is also reccomended in the rules.
Undated but it was probably in Austerity Britain in the 1950's (The rules say that there are only limited numbers of the game available, due to quota restrictions).

name: Sooty in Wonderland
description:
This is a roll and move game except that you don't roll dice. Instead, the roads on the board have brown lines at intervals and when you move you can only cross one brown line. These lines are diffent distances apart so one turn you may have a decent move, the next a poor one.
The object is to collect 4 special cards - Password Sesame, the Magic Wand, some Oofle Dust and the Key to the Chest. Three Treasure cards are turned face up. When you reach a star symbol on the board that matches one of the three face up cards, you may take one of these cards, then the display is refreshed.
There are Who Knows cards as well which act as Chance cards.
If you collect the four special cards, you must make your way to Sooty's Cave and claim the treasure in the Chest there.
It is suggested that you play a number of games and record the scores to decide a winner.

name: Jack of all Trades
description:
The game is played with a pack of 52 cards, made up of 12 tradesmen and a Burglar each using three tools. Players are dealt hands of four cards, and each turn must draw from the top of the deck or from the discard pile. After each draw, the player must discard a card face down. The first player to collect a set of a tradesman and his three tools wins the hand.

The adult version of the game is set up for gambling. Each person antes a coin at the start of each hand. The winner of the hand collects half the pot, but if he has included another tradesman's tool by mistake, he loses a like amount instead. If any player has the Burglar in hand, he must pay a penalty of half the pot - unless he also has the Bobby, in which case he takes the other half of the pot. Similarly, anyone holding one of the Burglar's tools (crowbar, mask or swag bag) pays a penalty of two coins each unless also holding one of the Bobby's tools (handcuffs, lantern or helmet).

There are also rules for young people that make the game a form of "Go Fish".
publishers: KUM-BAK Sports, Toys, & Games, MFG Co. Ltd, Pepys (Castell Brothers)

name: Waddy Golf
description:
This is a curious game, made in the 1930's, but is reminiscent of games a hundred years earlier.
The board is attractive and illustrates a track of 72 spaces. The first player to reach the end of the track wins. On the way to the end of the course, there are a number of Greens and Hazards. You need to roll a 6 to start. If you land on a space with an instruction on it, you must obey that instruction. These consist of things like 'Miss a turn', 'Hole in one, take another turn, Ball lost, take a detour, and so on.
An alternative board exists but presumably with the same rules.

name: Monster Bingo
description:
From Alex Toys: Bingo has never been so monstrously fun! Spin the spinner, match the monster to the one in your monster manor! Includes 4 double-sided bingo cards, 24 monster markers, spinner and easy instructions.

This is a basic bingo game where players hope to be the first to complete a row of three monsters on a 3x3 grid. The monster art is whimsical and each monster is wearing a different expression to help teach the very young the names of different emotions.

name: Gogo's Crazy Bones Trading Card Game
description:
A luck-heavy, ultra-simple card game for 2 players.

Decks must be 15+ cards and both players must use the same number of cards. To begin the game, players remove a 'leader' card from their deck. The objective of the game is to have a card attached to the leader in every orthogonal direction.

A round is 2 stages: firstly, each player selects a card from a hand of 3. Numbers and colours are compared: the higher number wins BUT if colours match, the round is a draw (both players win).

The winner(s) then either 'attach' the card orthogonally, in a way permitted by the arrows drawn on each card, or use its 'attack'. Attacks are special effects that change the game in some way.

name: Starburst
description: A solitaire game where the players try to complete a circuit using sequential placement of pawns. The player places 8 markers one at a time, each marker connected to the last. Play stops when there is no connected space to place a marker. At that point if all 8 markers are down the player wins.

name: Count Your Blessings
description:
From the Manufacturer:
Object of the game is to be the first player to flip their 4 tokens from "Stressed to Blessed", "Tired to Inspired", "Frazzled to Dazzled", and "Mad to Glad" simply by looking on the positive side of life! Spin the spinner, find the silver lining, and collect cards to come out a winner. Count Your Blessings is all about finding the "bright side" to each scenario on the cards, no matter how big the challenge, and seeing that every situation in life is full of "blessings-in-disguise". The Youngest player goes first by spinning the spinner. The corresponding card is read, a silver lining response is given, and in some cases, voted on. See specific card instructions below. Play continues in a clockwise direction until one player wins the game by turning all 4 tokens over to the sunny yellow side!

Contents:

1 sun spinner board,
215 game cards,
24 tokens,
6 heads or tails coins,
1 pair Look on the Brightside glasses

name: Dice Cricket
description:
Dice cricket is a dexterity and dice cricket game. There are no dates on the box or directions, but the general style suggests that it may be from the 1930s or 1940s. The directions (nothing as common as rules in this game) leave it to the players to decide how to organise the match - innings, numbers of players and so on.

Players put the pair of stumps about 5 to 6 feet apart ("the average length of an ordinary dining table" as the directions helpfully tell us). Dice are used as balls in the game. The bowler gently pitches a die (with faces 1, 2, 4, 6, out and NR (for no runs) to the batsman, preferably without the die touching the table. The batsman tries to hit it. If he misses and the stumps are hit, the batsman is out bowled. If he hits the die and it is caught by the bowler, the player is out caught. Otherwise, if he hits it, the result of the shot is shown by the top face of the die.

name: 2012: The Mayan Calendar
description:
The Mayan Calendar is much more than a system to mark off the passage of time. It is a prophetic calendar that may help us understand the past and foresee the future. It is a calendar of the Ages that describes how the progression of Heavens and Underworlds condition the human consciousness, and thus the frames for our thought and actions within a given Age.

To some people it is predicting the end of the world, December 2012. For others, the Calendar is forecasting the start of a new Era. This game incorporates both views.

The object of this game is to create a physical vehicle like a pyramid to focus and spread universal spiritual power. For this task we will need builders, materials, equipment and money. We must work together to build 11 Spiritual Centers around the Planet to ward off the many Destructive Perils entering from many directions. How much of the Earth did we allow to be destroyed? How much new spiritual consciousness did we bring into being?
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Cars 2 World GP travel game
description:
From publisher:
In this exhilarating new game, players get to race with the cars from the Disney film Cars 2. The players drive as fast and skilfully as possible to ensure the best possible result at the finishing line. During the race all cars have to visit the pit stop once. You have to choose the best time to do it. This makes the game a perfect blend of luck and very light strategy. Ready! Set! Drive!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Have-A-Go, The Wilfred Pickles Radio Party Game
description:
Trivia game linked to a very popular radio quiz hosted by Wilfred Pickles.

11 cards with 6 different questions on each one
1 Jackpot card
Rules

With so few questions provided, the replayability is very low.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: The Ides of March
description:
The Ides of March is a small game about the assassination of Julius Caesar. The premise is that Mark Anthony appears on the scene armed with a sword, albeit some distance from the scene. He has to either kill all the conspirators or get Caesar off the map before he is killed. Since he has a sword, he does considerably more damage with his attacks than the conspirators (armed with daggers) can manage.

The game contains rules, combat results table, map, and 10 counters, all printed on a single sheet of paper.

name: Dwyn
description:
A card game containing 6 different welsh characters broken up into a head, a torso, and feet. Players attempt for form a complete character, and then empty their hands except for the crown card (which is unique in the deck). Most cards in the deck allow you to swap or steal body parts from other players, creating mixed-up characters as the game proceeds.

From the Rules:
Each player tries to form a BODY consisting of three cards - HEAD, TORSO and FEET - either of different suits (good) or the same suit (best). In order to win, a player must form a BODY and get rid of all the cards in their hand, going out of play with only body parts in front of them with at least one each of a HEAD, TORSO and FEET and the KROWN card, with no other cards in their hand.

From the Box:
Whats Dwyn?
A game with lots of card swapping. A six suited poker deck divided into three colors, red, black and green with figures drawn from welsh history and popular culture. A fun new artwork by Simon Frennan and Christopher Sperandio. The result of an artists residency as part of the may-you-live-in-interesting-times festival of creative technology. The residency is findancially supported by Cywaith Cymru. Get rules for new games, and play an online version, just go to chapter.org or kartoonkings.com/dwyn.

Beth yw Dwyn?
Gem fywiog yn llawn o gyfnewid cardiau. Pecyn o gardiau mewn chew siwt wedi'u rhannu'n dri lliw, coch, du a gwyrdd, ynghyd a ffigyrau o hanes a diwylliant poblogiadd cymru. Gwaith celfyddydol hwyliog, newydd gan Simon Grennan a Christopher Sperandio. Canlyniad cyfnod preswyl yng MAY YOU LIVE IN INTERESTING TIMES, gyl technoleg greadigol caerdydd, a drefnwyd gan chapter a bloc. Carfwyd cefnogaeth ariannol i'r cyfnod preswyl gan cywaith cymru. I weld rheolau'r gem, ac i chwarae fersiwn ar-lien, ewch i chapter.org neu kartoonkings.com/dwyn.

name: Picture Hunt (Commencing Letters; All "D's")
description:
Party game. Up to 12 guests are given the same picture and it is suggested that they might try to find up to 60 objects in the picture that begin with a D. The one who makes the longest list (of correct answers, of course) wins.

Universal Publications Ltd. (U.P.L) published a series of games from London during the 1930s to the late 1950s. Special arrangements were made with manufacturers overseas to produce the popular UPL games. The Australian company G.N. Raymond was one company that was granted permission to produce UPL games.
publishers: G. N. Raymond, Party Games Publishers, Universal Publications Ltd

name: Quadruple Crossed
description:
This is game #11 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

In this game, players start with 8 pieces on the board and 4 off. Players try to get four of their pieces across the board, by either advancing them one space, or utilizing lines of pieces leap them over occupied spaces. Either of these moves types can be used to either advance to an unoccupied space or off the board.

name: Centre
description:
An abstract two-player strategy game, CENTRE (formally SPOOLS) has only a few basic rules of play that combine neatly with the unique design of the board to produce a new and different game.

By positioning and relocating pieces, players attempt to maneuver their own Emperor to the center circle of the board -- aided by their four Defenders and four Marauders, each of which possesses specific movement and attack capabilities.

Another unique aspect of the game is the one-way interaction between pieces: Defenders may attack only Marauders, Marauders may attack only Emperors, and Emperors may attack only Defenders and Marauders.

name: Tutti in Campo
description:
In this game each player must first form a team, moving on the path outside of the board, meeting events, financing, buying players.
When his team will be ready to enter the central area of the board, will play the matches.
Games against neutral teams (not represented by any player) the points value of the team will determine the winner, while against teams of the other participating in the game, you will shoot to door with the special ball, to determine the outcome of the challenge.
The victory means the gain of a card-challenge, the player who at the end of the game earned the highest number of cards-challenge win the game.

name: ReVicio
description:
This is Game #21 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

The game is loosely related to Reversi and Othello. In this game players enter pieces onto the board, and sliding other pieces down. Players remove a line of enemy pieces that are part of a custodial capture between two of a player's piece, one being slid and another one.

The game differs from Reversi and Othello in that players place all their pieces on the board, and instead of converting over when part of a custodial trap, the enemy pieces are removed from the board.

name: Winding Ascent
description:
The is Game #23 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This game is a diceless race game, where players move their pieces along a long and winding path to get their pieces to the End space, where they come off the board. Along the way, players are able to take shortcuts that accelerate their movement to the end, and also trap opposing pieces so they are not able to move.

name: One Six
description:
This is Game #26 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This is a solitaire puzzle game, with variant rules to enable it to be played as a party puzzle game. In it, players attempt to reduce 6 dice that are rolled to a single die on the board, with value of 6 on top. As players move dice, they reduce in value. As players merge dice, the new dice on the space merged equals the sum of the two dice merging. Players are not permitted to combine dice to a value greater than six, and each die is permitted to only move in a line, one or more spaces.

Quick rules:

Roll the six dice, and then place them on the board so they get reduced to a single die with a six on it.
As a die moves into another die, the value of the die moved into is increased by the current value of the die moving, and the die moving is removed from the board.
A single move for a die consists of moving in a straight line vertically, horizontally or diagonally, like a queen in chess. For each empty space a die moves into, it decreases its value by 1. A die may not be reduced to less than one doing this.
Each die can perform, at most, one move per puzzle.

name: Borgen
description:
Family game made after the popular Danish series running on DR1. Meet the characters from the popular series and use your knowledge to move to the position of power.
Answer question and move around board, collecting gold. Move to the center and pay the needed amount to win the game. Be the first to achieve that and win the game.

name: Intryga 13th Street
description:
Intryga 13th Street (The Intrigue of 13th Street) is a board game for 3-4 players aged 12+. The average time of play - about an hour.

Each player takes the role of one of the characters, which are: Kenneth Carter (Councillor), Kathlyn O'Brien (Detective), Gareth Newberry (Attorney), Emily Winfield (Technology) - in the past they were embroiled in an unsolved investigation. The goal is to reach the farthest field on the bonus track by discovering evidence of crime in investigations of other characters.

The game was realized as a giveaway for Hallmark Channel. As the execution time was frantically short (competitive companies abandoned the topic), Ku≈∫nia Gier has decided to alterate and adaptate one of its earlier criminal games - Inwigilacja. The game was well received by the customer, as evidenced by the second printing of the game in the second half of the year.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Crossroads: Talking About Teen Sexuality
description: Players move to the goal by answering trivia questions about teen sexuality, and explaining their answers to the other players. Just as in real life, being mistaken on a matter of teen sexuality may force you to deal with (special penalty questions about) teen pregnancy or sexually transmitted disease.

name: Indoor Soccer
description:
In this game 2 teams play an indoor soccer match.
The 2 players of this game both are coaches of one team.
Both coaches have 5 player figures (incl. the goalie).
A die determines your number of spaces to move one of your figures. If you reach the ball you shoot the ball by the unused number of pips on the die.
The die makes luck a part of this game. But your choices, like which player you move to which field and where to pass the ball are very important. For the following turns you calculate chances for your opponent and yourself and you try to have your players in good positions for later situations.

Predecessor of Streetsoccer.

name: The VCR Golf game
description: The object of VCR Golf game is to use the least amount of strokes, over 9 or 18 holes of golf. Exciting gameplay, combined with a VHS tape that includes over 250 shots featuring the premier PGA TOUR golfers, results in the most realistic golf game ever. And using your own ball and favorite putter, you can sink green shots with free putting cup included. Fore!

name: Pontate
description:
A card game with a little knowledge thrown into the mix. Each player starts with 10 counters (not provided).
Each player draws a card and places it in front of him and he contributes 1 counter to the Pool, and then the next player does the same, and so on until all the cards have been dealt and arrayed in front of each player. Now players (in turn) should look around the table and see if another card can be connected to one of his, to form the name of an Animal, Fish, Town, Bird, etc. As the number of cards to use goes down, it gets harder to come up with a right name.
Players are awarded points (in the form of counters from the Pool) and you can play a pre-sert number of games. The player with the most counters wins.

name: Reise ins Tierreich: Mitbringspiel
description:
Reise ins Tierreich: Mitbringspiel distills the essence of the board game Reise ins Tierreich, also released in 2011, into a tinier package with players once again trying to play animal cards that best other animal cards in certain values.

The game includes 33 animal cards – with a card showing one of six continents and one of five types of animals: mammal, amphibian, reptile, bird, fish – a set of ten category tokens and four "dice tokens". Each card shows the animal image on one side and has stats about that animal's weight, height/length, longevity and number of offspring on the other. Each player starts the game with three animal cards in hand, and the category tokens are placed in a circle with a shared pawn on one token.

On a player's turn, she throws the dice tokens, then moves the sum of the pips being shown. If she lands on a regular category token, she can use the side showing – say, "longevity, oldest" – or flip the token to the other side – which might be "offspring, fewest". Each player then chooses a card in hand and reveals it simultaneously. The player whose animal best fit the category places that animal card before her and draws a replacement card. Everyone else returns their card to hand.

If the player lands on a continent or animal token, she chooses a specific continent or animal type as well as one of the four animal stats and whether players want to be high or low. Each player then chooses an animal card and reveals, with the winning player(s) placing that card before them and drawing a replacement. (A player can swap out an entire hand of cards, but must sit out the next challenge.)

The first player to have five cards before her wins the game.

name: Mein Hundequiz
description:
Translated game description from the publisher:

What do you know about dogs? In this exciting trivia game, you can put your knowledge to the test and learn new and interesting things about dogs.

How does a dog's sense of smell compare to that of a man? What does a puppy get out of playing with a squeaky toy? The exciting questions and multiple choice answers in Mein Hundequiz are complemented by brilliant dog photos.

name: Periodic Quest: Card and Board Game Set
description:
Periodic Quest: Card and Board Game Set

Some of the games included in the set are described below

Atomic Rummy Card Game
Each player adds one card from the deck or play area to his/her collection and plays a card. Goal of each player is to make complete sets of cards that form well defined patterns on the Periodic Table. The game continues till the deck is empty. Player who comes up with patterns using maximum number of cards is the winner of the game. For 2 to 6 players, No prior chemistry knowledge required.

Atomic Number Card Game
Each player adds one card from the shuffled deck to his/here collection and places a card on the table from the collection. At the end of each round, the player who played the card with the highest value that matches the starting card type wins the round. The game continues until all the cards in the deck are played. The player with the highest sum of card value wins the game. For 4 to 8 players. No prior chemistry knowledge required.

Compound Formula Card Game
Each player adds one card from the shuffled deck to his/her collection and places a card on the table form the collection. If some or all cards on the table can be used to recreate formula of a chemical compound, the player claims those cards. The game continues until all the cards in the deck are played. The player with the highest sum of the cards value wins the game. For 4 to 8 players .Basic chemistry knowledge is required

Atomic Shell Card Game
Each player adds one card from the shuffled deck to his/her collection and place a card on the table form the collection. If the sum of electrons in the outer shells of the cards satisfies some predefined conditions, the player claims those cards. The game continues until all the cards in the deck are played. The player with the highest sum of card value wins the game. For 4 to 8 players

Explorer Board Game
This board game takes players through the Periodic Table and introduces them to various elements and encourages them to challenge their opponents in the understanding of the element properties. For 2 to 4 players . No prior chemistry knowledge required.

Challenger Board Game(s)
These board games challenge players in their ability to recall chemical compound formulas or to identify meaningful patterns on the Periodic Table. Players could maximize the chance of winning by strategically selecting the right combination of elements identified by face values of dice after rolling dice. For 2 to 4 players . No prior chemistry knowledge required for the Rummy version.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Travel
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Mars and Venus on a Date Question Card Game
description: A Pack of Provocative Questions that will Keep you Guessing what Men and Women are Thinking! Score Points by Successfully Guessing Other Players Answers. It's Thought Provoking fun for Whenever Friends get Together!

name: Duplicate Heartless: The Trick-taking Dice Game
description:
Duplicate Heartless is a trick-taking game that utilizes dice instead of cards.

In this game, dice are rolled and players use them to win tricks, rather than cards being shuffled. The dice act in a same manner as would cards with suits with value, like is done in the domino game 42.

In the game, the value on dice represent both the suit being led, and the value in the suit. After getting their dice to use for the round, a player will lead with die number, and players follow suit, and then follow up with the die. In Duplicate Heartless, the goal is to avoid taking trick, or shoot the moon, as is the case in Hearts.

The use of dice allows for a wide range of combinations that can come up during a round.

name: High School Musical 3: Center Stage Card Game
description:
Theme:
What would you do if you were one of the stars of High School Musical? This game asks players to put themselves in East High and answer questions as the cast of High School Musical would, or as you would in the same situation.

Game-play:
First - Pick the top card and read it allowed.
Second - Roll the D6 to find out who you are for this card. At the bottom of the card there is a key code.
Third - Then pick one of the answers and take the card of that color. Place the card face down in front of you.
Fourth - The other players then pick a card guessing which one the first picked.
Fifth - All players whose card matches the first players card gets a point

Goal:
First player to Five point wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music

name: The Jubilee Games Set
description:
In 1977, to commemorate the Silver Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth's reign, ZZota Games published a small boxed set of two games. Using the same board and tokens, Union Jack and The Great Quarter Century Race Game make up The Jubilee Games Set.

Union Jack is a two-player abstract placement game where you are trying to force your opponent to complete a set of red, white and blue tokens in a single line. Players alternate placing tokens on a 4 x 4 grid (with an extra space in the bottom left). Tokens must be placed in a proscribed order (red then white then blue). The player who is forced to complete a set of three colours anywhere in a vertical, horizontal or diagonal line is the loser.

In The Great Quarter Century Race Game, 2-3 players bluff and guess their way through the 25 spaces on the board. One player will hide a token in a hand and present both hands to the active player, who will select one. If the hand without the token is chosen, the active player advances on the track, otherwise it is the next player's turn. Some spaces will cause the token to advance further, and landing on a space occupied by another token will send that token backward on the track. The first to reach the middle square is the winner.

name: The Game of Games
description:
Party game where guests are given a personal question sheet on arrival and advised to answer the questions during the evening.
In this game, the 'questions' relate to the name of 24 games which are named by the cryptic clue.
For example;
Q. What is twice five
A. Tennis (Ten is)

name: The Roatan Island Game
description:
From the web-site:
Whether you are an aspiring Beach Bum, a wiley Business Owner, a crafty Investor or a burgeoning Divemaster this is the life for you!

Along the way explore the beautiful island of Roatan, take a water taxi trip to West Bay Beach, discover the iguana farm in French Harbor, dive in and gaze upon the Roatan Marine Park, journey through the Mangroves on a secret boat ride or try your luck at Chase the Ace in West End.

Whatever brings you to Roatan and wherever your adventures take you, enjoy hours of fun along the way playing The Roatan Island Game!Players choose their "Life Path" then go about the Island of Roatan in search of the Goals they need to fulfill their chosen Path and become Masters of their Life Path. Each Life Path is different so also are the Goals that make that life a success. Once you have acquired your Goals, you will be in pursuit of becoming the Governor of the Island of Roatan.

The rewards and pitfalls along the way make for an exciting and challenging part of the adventure as players wind their way through the Villages of Roatan in the typical small white taxi cabs found on the Island. However, these taxi cabs are color coordinated with the "Life Paths".

Along the way explore the Island, take a water taxi trip to West Bay, a secret boat ride through the Mangroves or play Chase the Ace.

Whatever brings you to Roatan and wherever you are going this game is sure to give you hours of fun along the way.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Meshok
description:
This game is another game in the Games on a Line Series of games.

In this game, players are challenged to occupy at least half of the board. During their turn, players do one of the three possible move types: place one more pieces on an empty space, remove one or more pieces from one of their stacks on the board, or move one of their pieces (or stacks). Players can remove pieces either through custodial capture, or moving one of their pieces as part of a group that is larger than a group of an opponent that is adjacent to the group that pieces are part of.

Meshok is the English spelling of how a word in Russian for "pocket" or "rucksack", connected also to the military term involving salients in lines during combat, is pronounced.

name: Pingu Acts Up
description:
A Pingu-themed gamed combining Roll & Move with Charades.
Players play as Pingu, Pinga, Bajoo or Robby the Seal & race to reach the start of the 'I See Slide'.
Along the way, there are 'Act Up' spaces where a player may draw a card & then perform the charade listed. these range from 'Brushing your teeth' & 'Flying a toy plane' to 'Pingu Boogaloo'. If the other players guess your charade, you keep the card & get the points listed on it.
Once a player has reached the start of the Slide, all players move there. Once someone crosses the finish line, the game is over.
The winner is the one who has scored the most points from their charades.

name: Im Kreuzverh√∂r
description:
As a criminalist you try to solve a murder by interrogating a witness. You can ask the witness about the characteristics and the motives of the culprit as well as about the found evidence.

A game consists of several rounds. In each round one of the players is the witness and randomly selects one of the cards indicating the guilty person. The criminalist whose turn it is shows the witness one of the characteristics, motives or evidence cards. The witness then answers (mostly truthfully, though there are exceptions, when he is allowed to lie or refuse the answer). Based on these answers the other players try to find the culprit. The aim is to be the first person to guess correctly. Then the next player becomes the new witness.

The game ends after all players have been the witness the same number of times.

name: Safety First
description:
Card game consisting of 52 cards featuring 5 sets of eight Citizen cards and four sets of three Vehicle Cards.

Shuffle them together then deal out an equal number of cards per player and everyone places their cards face-down in a pile in front of them. The game is played a little like Snap, but with a twist. As players reveal a card in their turn, "Safety First" must be called if two exposed cards match each other. However, if a vehicle card is exposed on any players' stack, then "Safety First" cannot be called, as the 'street' has a vehicle on it.

Players are urged to learn their Kerb Drill slogan;
Halt at the kerb.
Eyes right, Eyes left, Eyes right again
If the road is clear, quick march.

It is interesting that this advice was on children's TV 50 years later. Same advice but rebranded as the Green Cross Code.

Citizen cards illustrated by Harry Rowntree, the brilliant children's book artist. I have never come across any other game with a Harry Rowntree credit. NOTE: The artist was Harry Rountree but Jaques spelt it wrong on the box of this game. Now he is known with the Jaques spelling on some internet sites but Wikipedia confirms the correct spelling.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Transportation

name: Salute!
description:
Fast and furious card game.
There are 52 cards in four suits of service personnel. The four services are The Royal Navy, The Army, The Royal Air Force, and The Women's Auxiliary Territorial Services.
Deal out all the cards after shuffling. Each player does not look at their cards but makes a face-down pile in front of him. At the start players turn over their top card as fast as they can. Any number 1 card is placed in the middle of the table. From then on, you can earn 'Promotion' by playing a number 2 card of the same suit, then a number 3 card, and so on. The cards in the middle must be the right service to gain 'promotion', but you can also discard a card on any other player's face-up pack, obeying the promotion rule of the next highest card, but as it is not promoting a card in the middle of the table, any promotion card, regardless of suit can be played.
Play should be fast, because there are many penalty card laws and the rules say "The fun of the game relies on penalties being enforced".
The first player to get rid of all his cards is the winner.
The cards feature the insignia of rank in each of the four services. There is also a number in the corner of the cards so if you do not know the ranking, you can just remember to play the next higher card in that service.
The box exhorts players "Learn to spot the ranks".
This is a patriotic game in that players, especially children, were very interested in all things military. I would date the game as 1918 because the RAF (Royal Air Force) didn't exist before April that year. Previously it was the RFC (Royal Flying Corps)

name: Skits
description: Card Game. Each card represents one of the counties of England. In a turn, you play cards that relate to the county in play, or to a county adjacent to it on a map. The first card played will always be either Northumberland or Cornwall. If the former, play will proceed down the country, so-to-speak. If it is the latter play will proceed up the country.The first player to use all their cards, wins.

name: Stack Flip Crush Evict
description:
Stack Flip Crush Evict is a game that is played with a regular set of 24 checkers (two sets 12 checkers, each set a different color), and no board. Players are challenged to make 3 moves during their turn that consist of doing one of the following actions: stacking checkers on other checkers (or on the play are), flipping a stack, crushing a stack of opponent's checkers between a player's own pieces, or removing one of their free pieces from the board.

During play, the object is to either get 3 of their checkers in a stack together to be removed 4 times, or force their opponent to not have a legal move.

Included in the game is basic rules for play on a single stack

name: Safari photos
description:
Each player take pictures of wild animals.

Each player moves around on a course of 6 animals and have the ability to take pictures.

The winner is the player who made the best photos (15 points photos).

name: Tennis Game and Badminton
description:
One of Waddingtons' Target Series games, aimed at the customer on a strict budget.

Each player has a plastic 'racket' that is rather like a see-saw. You put the 'ball' onto your racket, push the handle of the racket down and, hopefully, the ball would land within the confines of the board. If successful, your opponent now returns the ball in the same way.

Both tennis and badminton play in the same way and you score as in the real rules for either sport.

Similar to Table Badminton

name: Knight Rider: K.I.T.T. Challenge Card Game
description:
A knight rider themed card game in which players try to build a road and then drive K.I.T.T. to safety. The game begins with each player playing a "Start" card, and placing their K.I.T.T. token upon it. Then, each player draws a card. The player with the highest number card wins all of the other cards, and then may do one of four things:
1. Build a section of their road by playing a card horizontally.
2. Move K.I.T.T. one space (if not hindered by a Hazard)
3. Play a Hazard card on another player's road
4. Play a Turbo Boost card to bypass a Hazard

The first player to build the correct length of road (7 units for 2p, 6 units for 3p and 5 units for 4p), play an "END MISSION" card, and drive K.I.T.T to the "END MISSION" card wins.

name: Electric Speedway
description:
A battery operated British game. In the 1930's, Speedway was a tremendously popular sport so companies were quite keen to add a Speedway game to their portfolio.

This is a game of chance, no skill required at all. The board has a wheel with six different coloured speedway bikes on it. Players are invited to put their bets on to a Roulette-like board. You could play for real money or buttons. When all the bets are placed, you flick a switch and the wheel will spin. As each bike goes past a connection, their colour light flashes on, so with a fast spinning wheel, the lights all flash, adding to the excitement. When the wheel stops, there will be one light on and that is the race winner. Winning punters collect their bets and another race can start. The winner must be the one who has the most money when the game ends.
publishers: British Games Ltd (BGL), J. Pressman &  Co., Inc.

name: Jumbles
description:
Party game that tests guests' sporting knowledge. Each guest is given a name of a sportsman, on a card but the letters spelling that name are all jumbled up. Guests are encouraged to mingle and, whilst chatting, casually ask each other if they can see their card and write down who they think the sportsman is. The one who identifies the most in the quickest time, wins.
Lots of variations of subject matter were also made by this publisher.

The games were mainly listed as being from the Dainty Series.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Errand Time
description: Children's party game. Each child is given a shopping list and an article card. The object is that each child will ask other guests what their article is. If that article is on their shopping list, then they can mark it off. First to complete their shopping list, wins

name: Strikeout
description: Sister game to Touchdown (an American Football game). Game consists of a large board depicting a baseball diamond, batter and pitcher cards, some standup figures, D6 dice and a scorepad. Game mechanics consist of Pitcher choosing a pitch card, batter choosing a type of swing, both players rolling a D6 and adding and subtracting modifiers according to the Batters or Pitchers mastercard. The result will be one of: Strike or Ball, Hit, Infield Hit, Deep Hit, Line Drive Catch and Flycatch or Home Run. Special rule cover stealing bases and the bunt.

name: Treasure Quest
description:
Party game.
Contents
18 Pirate cards
12 Treasure Island maps
The host places all the pirate cards (except card 1) around the room where they can be easily found and seen by the guests.He reads out the first Pirate card and players now look for the Pirate card next in sequence for their chosen route on their map card. When they find it they will be either right or wrong. If wrong, they must go back to their start position on the map. And play progresses like this until one player has discovered the exact location on their map card where the treasure is hidden. He or she wins.

name: Garden Courtship
description:
Party game, published under the Easy Chair Series of games by this publisher.
12 cards are distributed to 12 guests who want to play. The card takes the form of a story, with several blanks in them. You are given the first letter of the missing word and you must try to finish the story as it is read out by the host. All missing words are things that might be found in a flower garden. The most correct answers, wins.
An additional game is provided on the other side of the card and this is a simple Anagrams game. The first to get the 10 anagrams right, wins. All ten anagrams are names of motor cars.
publishers: G. N. Raymond, Party Games Publishers, Universal Publications Ltd

name: Streets of London
description: Card game about collecting sets but this has a twist in that sets are of unequal sizes, from 2 card sets to 5 card sets. The cards picture street characters in Victorian London, who call out their wares or services, such as "Oranges, two a penny". At the bottom of the illustration in this case, it says Oranges. The associated three other cards in this set say Two, A, and Penny.

name: Leap Over
description:
A Chinese Checkers-style game

From website;

Start: 10 stones of their own color for each player on the triangular sections whose point is the center of a side of the board

Play: Take turns jumping any one of your stones over another stone directly next to it, to an empty intersection immediately on the other side of the stone being jumped, on the same straight line from which the jump began. A stone may jump over stones of either color, in any direction on the board, and over more than one stone, as long as it touches down after each one. The jumping stone may change direction at the end of any one leap in a series. Stones on the outer edge of the board can be jumped over only by stones also on the outer edge.

Jumps over stones at the center of any "pentagon" may follow either fork on the other side of the pentagon. Every move must be a leap.

Goal: To be the first player to move all stones into the opponent's start position.

name: Motor Racing
description: A simple roll-and-move 1950's motor racing game. Land on a green or red square, you must follow the instructions (good or bad). First to reach the end of the track, wins.

name: Roulette
description:
A simple British game from the 1920's. Any number of players can play. In your turn you spin the spinner and when it stops an arrow will be pointing at one colour. Each colour is worth different numbers of points. You score the points and then it is the next player's turn. I said it was simple!
It would be a little more interesting if players bet beforehand on the colour that would be arrowed. At least then all players would be interested in the result of the spin.

name: Pocket Quiz: Expressionismus
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "Expressionism" and the questions are about that style of art.

name: Die Welt der Sterne
description:
"The world of stars" in English
On 32 cards there are 2 questions with three answers each, on the back with information and illustration on the subject. Players receive questions cards, in case of 3 and 4 players also betting cards.

The active player is asked by the quizmaster, if the first answer is right, he is asked the second question. If the answer is again correct, the player receives the card and places it with his betting cards. In case the first answer was wrong the left neighbour of the player can risk an answer and use one of his betting cards. If he answers wrong, he loses he card. When no one has questions cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

name: Planeten & Raumfahrt Quiz-Spiel
description:
"Planetary & Space Quiz Game" in English

32 cards show 2 questions with 3 answers each, on the backside information and illustrations on the subject are given. Players receive quest cards and betting cards for 3 and 4 players. The quiz master poses a question to his neighbour, in case of a correct answer also the second questions – if both are correct the candidate receives the card. If the first answer is wrong, the neighbour of the candidate can risk a betting card and try to answer. If he answers wrong, he loses the card. If nobody has cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

name: Ritter & Burgen Quiz-Spiel
description:
"Knights & Castles quiz game" in English

32 cards show 2 questions with three answers each, the back side shows information and illustration on the subject. Players have question cards and risk cards, the starting player chooses a card and the candidate on his left tries to answer the first question - if he is right, the second is asked. In case of two correct answers the candidate receives the card and puts it with his risk cards. If the first answer is wrong, the left neighbour of the candidate can take over by risking one of his risk cards - if he answers wrong he loses the card. At the end the player with the most cards wins.

name: Goldnaire
description:
You are a renowned gold jeweler – a master craftsman – but are you proficient enough to claim the title Goldnaire?

Players start with a hand of six cards, with the cards showing various types of jewelry. On a turn, you lay down 1-2 types of jewelry on the table in front of you, then trade with other players for the cards in their hands while trading away what you hold. After trading, you may lay down additional cards from your hand if they match the two types on the table in front of you.

If you have enough points on the table, you can then trade them in for one or more gold bars from the stack. As the gold bars are claimed, the point value needed to claim more rises.

You can discard cards from your hand, but you receive a penalty point when doing so; alternatively, you can donate cards to other players. At the end of your turn, you refill your hand to six cards.

When the last gold bar is claimed, the game ends. Who will be the Goldnaire?

name: Einsteigen bitte!
description:
German card game. 31 cards. Each card has three types of train;
Personenzug = Local train
Eilzug = Fast train
D - Zug = Very fast train

Underneath each designation there is the name of a city which will have a railway station.

The game plays a little like Rummy in that you are trying to lay down sets of cities that are linked by one of the three train types. In other words, a train route.

First to play all their cards wins.

I think this must have required seriously good knowledge of trains and their destinations. I mean, is it likely that someone living in Hamburg would know a local train route around Munich? Perhaps it was only aimed at keen railway fans.

name: The Tufty Game
description: A simple roll and move game. If you land on an instruction, you must obey it. This was the first Spears game featuring Tufty the Squirrel.

name: The 64,000 Question
description:
A party game for trivia enthusiasts. Volunteer guests are asked trivia questions and the guest who gets the most correct, wins.
Questions and answers provided by the Encyclopedia Britannica.
The box says it is related to the television show, but, as it is just quiz questions, the company could have said it was related to hundreds of other TV game-shows!

Note the odd title - not a pound or dollar sign at all.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Crazy Maze
description:
Descibed on the box as "The Remote Control Maze Game".
Crazy Maze has proved to be a very difficult game, as you have to navigate the maze without dropping into the traps all while climbing the incline. The inner ring is about one inch higher than the outer ring (when the maze is level).

Play for a pre-decided time limit and the winner is either the player that moved the ball furthest or the one who completes the maze in the fastest time.

name: Skittle Tennis
description:
Everyone knows the garden game where you have a tennis ball attached to a rope so that when you whack it, it spins around a central pole so that the other player can hit it back again. Well, this is the indoor equivalent. All made of plastic and a soft ball, you can recreate the garden game beautifully.

As usual with a new Aurora Skittle game, Don Adams (of Get Smart fame) is on the cover, but here he looks a little bored. Maybe he is thinking "I have done too many skittle games.......".

name: Hollywood Studio
description: Starting with $25,000 and a studio car, players traverse the gameboard with script in hand with the goal of meeting the requirements to complete their movies. Players roll and move with the usual assortment of chance elements found in board games such as these, but they are free trade and barter at will. The first to complete one’s assigned script requirements is the winner.
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation

name: Macius: Hurra, heute ist Maskenball!
description: There are 16 characters from the stories of the little king Macius in this game. Each character consists of four cards (hat, head, belly and legs). The players roll the dice and try to collect all cards and whoever has the most complete figures at the end of the game wins.

name: Quer durch Europa
description:
Objective: be the first to visit 5 capital cities within Europe
- moving by turn -
1st choose side of the map (geographical or political)
2nd draw card to find starting position
3rd draw additional 5 cards and 'form' a route
4th roll the die and move your meeple
5th you may use cards (max 2 =) ship and plane tickets instead of your die
5th if the roll shows a symbol draw an action card and proceed
as described

name: Pizza Stibizza
description:
Objective: get as many precious ingredients as possible - avoid those with lemons
1 each player receives a (blank) pizza board and a 'fork' in his own colour
2 ingredients are placed on the board - sunny side up (some have a printed lemon on the backside)
3 player rolls the die and must move his fork along the board in a straight line - but not transverse - and may make one 90° turn
4 if there is an ingredient, take it and put it on your pizza
do not show other players the backside of your ingredient; leave your fork where you took the ingredient
5 if someone lands on a fork he may snitch 3 ingredients from the fork's owner and put the fork on the pizza (starting place)
6 game ends until all ingredients are picked
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Set Collection

name: Wer Beobachtet Besser?
description:
A game for two that tests your powers of observation. There are two decks of cards, 40 cards per deck. The cards show a grid of 6 squares 4 of which are blank and two have either a red triangle or a red circle, or, indeed, a blue triangle or a blue circle. Each card will have a red and a blue example of the shape.

Each player shuffles their deck and then gives it to his or her opponent. Interestingly, it is allowed to shuffle them with some cards the wrong way round. Not sure if this adds to the difficulty or not.

At the word Go, both players start searching through the deck they have been given. The object is to find a matching pair. No two cards are identical so a pair is two cards that have the two shapes reversed, so to speak. For example, if a card had a Blue triangle in the top left corner and a red circle in the bottom right corner, the the matching card will be one thast has a red triangle in the top left corner and a blue triangle in the bottom right corner.

The first player to match the 20 pairs available, wins

name: "Battle of Britain" Game
description:
Air battle game for 2 players played on a hex grid. Both players receive 12 planes and the game ends when one player has lost all planes.

The game is played on a board which is a side view of sky. Planes move d6 hexes and can shoot down enemy planes if they stop exactly behind or above the enemy plane. The first move is always straight and maximum of three planes can be moved in one turn, all planes move the same number of hexes.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Baquartet
description:
User summary:
A simple dice game starring characters from Toho fame. Players take turns rolling the character dice. Any character but the Fairy Queen may be kept and the others rerolled. A three-dice, full house, four-dice or five-dice (of anything but the Fairy Queen) is worth points. Also, the quartet of all four idiots (Cirno, Lumia, Wriggle and Mystia) plus Fairy Queen also gives points.

The first player to a set number of points wins.

The games comes with 5 dice, a score sheet and a handkerchief to roll the dice on.

For 1 to 5 players, aged older than the March Fairy.

name: Ollaan kimpassa
description: Pairs draw cards which have body parts, for example fingers-fingers or thumb-forehead and the pair has to place card between those body parts. Pairs continue to add more cards, when first card falls the game is over for that pair.

name: Total Conflict
description:
"A practical set of World War-III wargaming rules for MICRO & HO scale enthusiast [sic]"

Micro armor scale miniature wargame rules for the Superpower's war that (thankfully) never happened.

This is a comprehensive rules set, with rules covering combat engineers, sighting weapons, transport capabilities, airdrops and air assaults, aircraft, morale, and tactical nuclear strikes. It also includes a short (four pages) chapter with orders of battles for American, British, West German, and Soviet units.

name: Oliver & Co.
description:
Objective: find Jenny - caught and hidden by Bill Sykes - and be the first leading her home
- simple 'Roll and Move' game, moving by turn -
1. find Jenny entering houses and flipping cards
2. announce if you found her
3. bring her home (house in Park Avenue)
4. avoid to be caught by players (loose a card)
5. avoid to meet Bill Sykes (drop a card)
5. don't eat too many hot dogs (forced by cards)
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Jet-Set Business
description: The players set up tourism companies from hotel chains, restaurants, clubs and holiday airlines and try to get 100 millions of money first. The player rolls and moves in his turn, also he takes a card. On a 4-star field he may buy or sell or trade, the prices will be determined by the rate table.

name: Crayola-Opoly
description: Roll and move around your typical mini-Monopoly board, colouring in the squares you land in with crayons to signal ownership. Each player starts with a posse of crayon pieces and the aim is to not lose your crayons to other players (by landing on their squares) whilst winning their crayons.

name: Sphinx
description:
A single player game of archaeological exploring through a twisting network of tunnels discovered hidden beneath the Great Sphinx. Five treasures are rumored to be secreted within. Can you find them all?

Sphinx uses the Shibumi game board and pieces to create the labyrinth as you go. And makes use of 10 white spheres, 15 black spheres and 5 red spheres as well as one red to represent the explorer.

name: B√ºrgermeisterspiel: Werde B√ºrgermeister in Quedlinburg
description:
Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Quedlinburg
- simple 'Roll and Move' game, very similar to Monopoly , moving by turn -
Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instruction of space landed on, buys - if possible and/or preferable - votes ;
that's more or less the only difference compared with Monopoly;
"chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Quedlinburg
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Kelly's Activity pocket
description:
Another promotional version of Activity for Kelly's.
This is pocket edition of Activity task cards only.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Team-Based Game

description:
Game is based on the format of a hugely successful gameshow in Britain. The show ran from 1978 to 1988. The host throughout was comedian Ted Rogers (1935 - 2001), pictured on the cover.

With the help of cryptic clues, players must solve them (and more routine quiz questions), and to thus eliminate other players from the game.

The TV show's star was Dusty Bin (also on the cover), a cartoon dustbin. If you failed to win a big prize all you got was a ceramic Dusty Bin figure.

name: 'Over a Thousand' Question Quiz
description:
British game made by Peter Pan Playthings to compete with the Spear's game Tell Me: The Grand Quiz Game. Like the Spear's game, this has a spinner, which you use to generate the letter that the answer must begin with. But this game also has a second spinner (instead of cards as in Tell Me), which generates the question.

You get various discs which can change the results of the question spinner. The six discs relate to the subjects of Sport, Nature, Personal, Geography, General Knowledge (1) and General Knowledge (2).

The first to reach a pre-decided number of correct answers, wins.

name: Dartabout
description:
The introduction to the rule book says "'DARTABOUT' is a really good game and one which we feel sure will be universally popular. .. it has only five simple rules of play .. The object of the game is for each player to move his five men across the board from his own 'starts' and occupy the 'starts' of the player opposite to him, doing as much 'damage' to his opponents as is compatible with skilful play."

As with the same maker's Sorry!, pieces are moved via playing cards. Some ('straight') cards move a piece forwards so many squares, other ('bent') cards mean the piece must make a 90 degree turn as part of its move. Three special cards exist: '69' can be treated either as a straight six or a bent nine; '8' allow two pieces to be moved a combined total of eight spaces forward; and '1' allows a piece to move one square forwards or sideways. Opposing pieces not on safety square which are landed on are 'bumped' off onto an unfavourable start square.

The main game involves dealing out the deck between the players who can then pick which card to play each turn. If the game has not finished, the discards are shuffled and dealt again. A version for children involves picking cards at random to play each turn.
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Punter
description:
A horse racing themed card game.

One player is the Bookie and will offer odds on each race. Those odds are determined by how many cards of each colour are randomly drawn before the race starts. If only one red card is drawn, the odds will be better than a colour that has no cards drawn. If 2 are drawn for one colour, the odds increase. And so on. The odds reflect the fact that there are less cards in the deck for that colour to win.

Having established the odds and all bets are placed, the race begins. The Bookie turns over a card and that colour advances one card length. A horse needs to be moved 7 card lengths first to win.

There are some wild cards that have certain effects. They tend to affect the race of the next card to be revealed. For example, if you drew a Blue Horse Stumbles card, the Blue horse is moved forward as usual. But the next colour card drawn has to suffer the effects of having stumbled.

The winner at the end of the evening is the player with the most cash. I would suggest you might end it after every player has had one turn of being the Bookie.
